58e17f3a-8b2c-41a6-8332-72812d2b277b NOTES
58e17f3a-8b2c-41a6-8332-72812d2b277b Cut bacon slabs onto sizes that will fit reasonably tight into your curing container.
58e17f3a-8b2c-41a6-8332-72812d2b277b Rub in 1/2 dry mix into all areas of bacon and place the slabs skin down for 48 hours. Cure at 40° F, 4° C.
58e17f3a-8b2c-41a6-8332-72812d2b277b Restack the bacon slabs: top ones go on the bottom and the bottom ones on top. Apply the remaining 1/2 of curing solution when restacking the pieces. Cure for additional 48 hours at 40° F, 4° C.
58e17f3a-8b2c-41a6-8332-72812d2b277b Make a hanging loop on one end and hang bacon for 2-3 hours in a cooler to drain and dry. When the surface feels dry, proceed to smoking.
58e17f3a-8b2c-41a6-8332-72812d2b277b Place bacon in a preheated to 122° F, 50° C, smokehouse and when bacon feels dry, apply warm smoke (86-104° F, 30-40° C) for about 2 hours until the skin becomes yellow.
58e17f3a-8b2c-41a6-8332-72812d2b277b Start preparing liquid stock broth before smoking bacon.
58e17f3a-8b2c-41a6-8332-72812d2b277b Pour gelatin powder (if used) on the bottom of the can.
58e17f3a-8b2c-41a6-8332-72812d2b277b Cut bacon into strips that will fit the height of the can best (remember about headspace). They may be rolled (wrapped) around. Add 820 g (28 oz) of bacon, you should not have no more than 3 principal pieces. If more bacon is needed, cut a strip size that complement one of the main strips.
58e17f3a-8b2c-41a6-8332-72812d2b277b Pack the bacon into the cans leaving 1/2" headspace. Add broth to 1/2 inch from top.
58e17f3a-8b2c-41a6-8332-72812d2b277b Exhaust cans to 170° F, 77° C meat temperature.
58e17f3a-8b2c-41a6-8332-72812d2b277b Stir carefully removing the air from the bottom and sides, then add more hot liquid to 1/4" from top. Seal immediately and process at once at 240° F, 116° C:
f15d8c78-35fb-4934-9d0c-65af5cb64bbf Soak dry peas in cold water for 12 hours. Stir often.
f15d8c78-35fb-4934-9d0c-65af5cb64bbf Add water to pot equipped with a steamer basked and bring to a boil. Place soaked peas in a steamer basket and cook for 3 minutes, shaking the pot a few times to make sure that all peas are scalded equally. Drain peas on screens.
f15d8c78-35fb-4934-9d0c-65af5cb64bbf Dice onion and fry in lard until golden.
f15d8c78-35fb-4934-9d0c-65af5cb64bbf Cook smoked bacon for 3 minutes in boiling water. Cut bacon into pieces about 2-1/2 oz (70 g) each.
f15d8c78-35fb-4934-9d0c-65af5cb64bbf Mix peas with onion, salt and marjoram. Add peas and mix again.
f15d8c78-35fb-4934-9d0c-65af5cb64bbf Pack each can with one piece of smoked bacon, then fill with peas.
f15d8c78-35fb-4934-9d0c-65af5cb64bbf Add water, leaving 1/2 headspace.
f15d8c78-35fb-4934-9d0c-65af5cb64bbf Exhaust cans to 170° F, 77° C meat temperature. Fill with hot water to 1/4 inch from top.
f15d8c78-35fb-4934-9d0c-65af5cb64bbf Seal and process at once at 250° F, 121° C: 307x200.25 - 45 min
bfb3bef4-317d-419e-857c-e22483536b6b Soak dry peas in water for 3 hours. Stir.
bfb3bef4-317d-419e-857c-e22483536b6b Dice the onion and fry in lard until golden.
bfb3bef4-317d-419e-857c-e22483536b6b Cut bacon into pieces about 2-1/2 oz (70 g) each.
bfb3bef4-317d-419e-857c-e22483536b6b Add 1 quart (1 liter) of water to a skillet and add bones. Bring to a boil and slow boil for 3 hours. Add all ingredients and boil additional hour (total boil 4 hours). Strain the stock and mix with fried onions.
bfb3bef4-317d-419e-857c-e22483536b6b Place in each jar: 1-2 pieces of bacon, peas and fill with hot stock leaving 1 inch headspace. Seal and process at once at 250° F, 121° C:
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 NOTE Original processing times for metric jars were:
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 The final product consists of pieces of meat bound together with natural gelatin. When kept cold, it should remain in one piece. The product is covered with natural gelatin (aspic, meat jelly). The might be some melted fat on the top and the bottom.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 Clean heads from any remaining glands and bloody areas.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 Skins.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 Finely chop onion and fry in lard until golden.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 Grinding meat.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 Mix all meats with spices well together until mixture becomes sticky.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 Fill the jars leaving 1 inch headspace.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 Process at 250° F, 121° C:
5941455d-48ed-4159-a22d-efe8da3dcd81 CFR 9, ß 319.304 Meat stews.
5941455d-48ed-4159-a22d-efe8da3dcd81 Meat stews such as "Beef Stew" or "Lamb Stew" shall contain not less than 25 percent of meat of the species named on the label, computed on the weight of the fresh meat.
5941455d-48ed-4159-a22d-efe8da3dcd81 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
5941455d-48ed-4159-a22d-efe8da3dcd81 Peel potatoes, onions and carrots, then dice them. Keep freshly peeled potatoes under water to prevent darkening.
5941455d-48ed-4159-a22d-efe8da3dcd81 Trim beef, remove gristle and fat, cut meat into 1 inch (25 mm) cubes. Brown in a small amount of fat. Boil potatoes for 10 minutes. Mix flour with water, salt, and pepper to make gravy. Add hot meat and potatoes, vegetables and top with hot gravy leaving 1î headspace in glass jars and 1/4î headspace in cans. Remove air bubbles.
5941455d-48ed-4159-a22d-efe8da3dcd81 Adjust lids in glass jars and seal the cans. Process at once at 240° F, 116° C.
3fc21624-3d3f-4193-b21b-299b9bad0bcb Cut beef into 1 inch (25 mm) pieces. Cut jowl (bacon) into 1/2" (12 mm) pieces or grind through 1/2" (12 mm) plate.
3fc21624-3d3f-4193-b21b-299b9bad0bcb Cut onion into thin discs and fry in lard until golden.
3fc21624-3d3f-4193-b21b-299b9bad0bcb Place bones in 600 ml (20 oz) water and simmer at 194-203° F, 90-95° C for 3 hours. Add allspice, bay leaf, celery and parsley. Simmer additional 60 minutes. Strain the stock.
3fc21624-3d3f-4193-b21b-299b9bad0bcb Wash buckwheat grouts. Place ground jowl/bacon in a pot and heat until there is some fat. Add buckwheat grouts, and 200 ml (7.76 oz) bone stock and slow cook for 60 minutes, stirring often. At the end, add fried onions and mix all together.
3fc21624-3d3f-4193-b21b-299b9bad0bcb Add meat pieces to the pot and mix all together.
3fc21624-3d3f-4193-b21b-299b9bad0bcb Pack 120 g (4.23 oz) of the product into the can and pour 80 ml ( 2.71 oz) bone stock, leaving 1/2 headspace.
3fc21624-3d3f-4193-b21b-299b9bad0bcb Exhaust cans to 170° F, 77° C meat temperature.
3fc21624-3d3f-4193-b21b-299b9bad0bcb Seal and process at once at 250° F, 121° C: 307x200.25 - 45 min
ea3b9668-0f31-4427-87c0-dde6d5c07c09 Place bones and ribs in a skillet and add enough water to cover. Bring to a boil, reduce heat, cover with a lid and simmer until the meat is semi-soft. Remove the ribs and separate the meat from the bones. Place bones back in the skillet and simmer for additional 3 hours. Remove bone and remove all meat. Filter the stock through a fine sieve. Cut the rib meat into 30 mm (3/4") pieces.
ea3b9668-0f31-4427-87c0-dde6d5c07c09 Place cabbage in a pot and add equal by weight amount of the meat stock. Add caraway, bay leaf and cut up mushrooms and simmer everything together for 4 hours. Do not cover with the lid. Replace the meat stock lost during evaporation with more stock.
ea3b9668-0f31-4427-87c0-dde6d5c07c09 Melt 1/2 lard in a frying pan, then fry cut up onion just to soften it. Add beef and pork cubes and simmer for 30 minutes. Add bacon and sausage and simmer for additional 20 minutes. Stir often to prevent burning.
ea3b9668-0f31-4427-87c0-dde6d5c07c09 Add the following to the cooked cabbage: browned beef and pork, onion, salt, all boiled meat that was separated from the bones, and simmer for 60 minutes, stirring often. The stew should not be covered with liquid sauce, however, the sauce should come up when the stew is pressed with the spoon. Let it cool enough to be able to handle it. Add pepper and remix the stew.
ea3b9668-0f31-4427-87c0-dde6d5c07c09 Fill 307x200.25 mm cans with hot stew leaving 1/4 inch headspace.
ea3b9668-0f31-4427-87c0-dde6d5c07c09 Process at once 240° F, 116° C for 60 minutes.
e4c966c8-90a9-4d6a-aba8-b09b416f8d8d Wash beans thoroughly and place them in a 2 qt. saucepan. Add cold water to a level of 2 to 3 inches above the beans and soak 12 to 18 hours. Drain and discard water. Combine beans with 5Ω cups of fresh water and 2 teaspoons salt. Bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer 30 minutes. Drain and discard water. Brown ground beef, chopped onions, and peppers (if desired), in a skillet. Drain off fat and add 3 teaspoons of salt, pepper, chili powder, tomatoes and drained cooked beans. Simmer 5 minutes.
e4c966c8-90a9-4d6a-aba8-b09b416f8d8d CAUTION Do not thicken. Fill hot jars, leaving 1 inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
e4c966c8-90a9-4d6a-aba8-b09b416f8d8d For processing at above 1,000 ft, see page Altitude Adjustments.
dc9e7011-c7ab-46e3-94cc-14929c058c01 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
dc9e7011-c7ab-46e3-94cc-14929c058c01 Wash the corned beef, cut into pieces suited for packing.
dc9e7011-c7ab-46e3-94cc-14929c058c01 Cover meat with cold water and bring to boil. If broth tastes very salty, strain and cover meat with fresh water, and parboil again.
dc9e7011-c7ab-46e3-94cc-14929c058c01 Pack hot meat. Leave about 1 inch above meat in glass jars for headspace. Leave 1-1/2 inch in cans.
dc9e7011-c7ab-46e3-94cc-14929c058c01 Cover meat with hot broth or hot water. Leave 1 inch for headspace in jars, fill cans to top.
dc9e7011-c7ab-46e3-94cc-14929c058c01 Work out bubbles with knife.
dc9e7011-c7ab-46e3-94cc-14929c058c01 Seal and process at once.
e88008e7-04d3-4d5c-95d6-9434d824763f cook suet and meat in water to avoid browning. Peel, core, and quarter apples. Put meat, suet, and apples through food grinder using a medium blade. Combine all ingredients in a large saucepan, and simmer 1 hour or until slightly thickened. Stir often. Fill jars with mixture without delay, leaving 1-inch headspace. Adjust lids and process.
e88008e7-04d3-4d5c-95d6-9434d824763f For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
e892e800-4ff3-4fc3-9762-aad6bdb6683b Because of flavor, it is best to can livers alone. Gizzards and hearts, may be canned together. Since they are ordinarily canned and used in small quantities, directions are given only for pint glass jars and no. 2 cans.
e892e800-4ff3-4fc3-9762-aad6bdb6683b For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
e892e800-4ff3-4fc3-9762-aad6bdb6683b Put giblets in cooking pan. Cover with broth made from bony pieces, or hot water. Cover pan and precook giblets until medium done. Stir occasionally.
e892e800-4ff3-4fc3-9762-aad6bdb6683b If salt is desired, put level measure into clean, empty containers: 1/2 teaspoon in pint jar or No. 2 can.
e892e800-4ff3-4fc3-9762-aad6bdb6683b Pack giblets hot. Leave about 1 inch above meat in glass jars for head space, 1/2 inch in cans.
e892e800-4ff3-4fc3-9762-aad6bdb6683b Cover giblets with hot broth or hot water. Leave 1 inch for head space in jars, fill cans to top.
e892e800-4ff3-4fc3-9762-aad6bdb6683b Work out air bubbles with knife. Add more liquid, if needed, to cover meat. Be sure to leave 1 inch headspace in jars and have cans filled to top.
e892e800-4ff3-4fc3-9762-aad6bdb6683b Adjust lids on glass jars, seal cans.
e892e800-4ff3-4fc3-9762-aad6bdb6683b Process at once in the steam pressure canner at 10 pounds pressure (240° F, 116° C).
889caa9b-528f-4698-b410-c58715ec02e4 Choose fresh, chilled meat. For venison, add one part high-quality pork fat to three or four parts venison before grinding. Season freshly made sausage with salt and cayenne pepper (sage may cause a bitter off-flavor).
889caa9b-528f-4698-b410-c58715ec02e4 Bear, beef, lamb, pork, sausage, veal, venison.
889caa9b-528f-4698-b410-c58715ec02e4 Hot Pack - shape chopped meat into patties or balls or cut cased sausage into 3 to 4 inch links. Cook until lightly browned. Ground meat may be sauteed without shaping. Remove excess fat. Fill hot jars with pieces. Add boiling meat broth, tomato juice, or water, leaving 1 inch headspace. Remove air bubbles, adjust headspace if needed. Add 1 teaspoon of salt per quart, 1/2 teaspoon per pint, if desired. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
889caa9b-528f-4698-b410-c58715ec02e4 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
889caa9b-528f-4698-b410-c58715ec02e4 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
889caa9b-528f-4698-b410-c58715ec02e4 * Raw pack is suitable only for cans. It is difficult to remove ground meat out of glass jars when packed this way.
889caa9b-528f-4698-b410-c58715ec02e4 Raw Pack - without forming cakes, pack raw ground meat solidly into cans level with top. Place cans in a pot with water about 2 inches below can rim. Exhaust (cook) at slow boil until meat registers 170° F, 77° C. Press meat down into cans leaving 1/2 inch headspace. Seal and process at once.
23220466-d9c0-42a4-9c08-8828ebe54148 Grind scraps of lean meat, or meat from less tender cuts. Season with 1 tsp. salt to 1 pound ground meat. Mix well.
23220466-d9c0-42a4-9c08-8828ebe54148 Raw Pack* - Suitable only for cans.
23220466-d9c0-42a4-9c08-8828ebe54148 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
23220466-d9c0-42a4-9c08-8828ebe54148 Form meat into small fairly thin, flat cakes, uniform in thickness (not humped in middle). Make them of a size to pack into the containers without breaking.
23220466-d9c0-42a4-9c08-8828ebe54148 Place meat cakes in heavy baking pan, oiled slightly if necessary to prevent sticking. Precook in moderate oven until medium done. Cakes are heated enough when they show almost no red color at center when cut.
23220466-d9c0-42a4-9c08-8828ebe54148 Pack cakes hot. Leave one-inch space above meat in glass jars; 1/2 inch in tin cans.
23220466-d9c0-42a4-9c08-8828ebe54148 Cover meat with hot liquid (pan drippings with fat skimmed off, meat broth, or water). Again leave 1 inch space above liquid in glass jars. Fill tin cans to top.
23220466-d9c0-42a4-9c08-8828ebe54148 Work out air bubbles. Add more liquid if necessary; leave 1 inch above liquid in glass jars, fill cans to top.
23220466-d9c0-42a4-9c08-8828ebe54148 Seal and process at once.
23220466-d9c0-42a4-9c08-8828ebe54148 Pack ground raw meat solidly into tin cans, level with the top.
23220466-d9c0-42a4-9c08-8828ebe54148 Place open can in large vessel of water and heat as directed above for raw pack of cut pieces of meat.
23220466-d9c0-42a4-9c08-8828ebe54148 Press meat down about 1/2 inch below rim of can. Seal can and process at once.
a6b7d462-659f-44b8-afdd-752d591f8d09 Heart - remove thick connective tissue before cutting into pieces.
a6b7d462-659f-44b8-afdd-752d591f8d09 Tongue - drop tongue into boiling water and simmer about 45 minutes or until skin can be removed, before cutting into pieces.
a6b7d462-659f-44b8-afdd-752d591f8d09 The heart and tongue are generally used as fresh meat. If you do wish to can them follow directions for beef, veal, pork, lamb as hot packed.
a6b7d462-659f-44b8-afdd-752d591f8d09 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
a6b7d462-659f-44b8-afdd-752d591f8d09 Place hearts in boiling water. Simmer 15-20 minutes.
a6b7d462-659f-44b8-afdd-752d591f8d09 Reheat the prepared tongues in the broth or hot water.
a6b7d462-659f-44b8-afdd-752d591f8d09 Add 1 teaspoon of salt per quart to the jar, 1/2 teaspoon to pints, if desired.
a6b7d462-659f-44b8-afdd-752d591f8d09 Pack heart or tongue hot. Leave one inch headspace in glass jars, 1/2 inch in cans.
a6b7d462-659f-44b8-afdd-752d591f8d09 Cover meat with the hot pre-cooking liquid. Leave one inch space above liquid in glass jars, fill cans to top. Work out bubbles with a knife.
a6b7d462-659f-44b8-afdd-752d591f8d09 Seal and process at once at 10 pounds pressure (240° F, 116° C).
c15bc6a2-e898-4943-b794-4be0db5f54d0 Soak beans for 12 hours in water. Stir. Dry beans must gain 85% in weight (use scale). If more weight gain is needed soak beans longer.
c15bc6a2-e898-4943-b794-4be0db5f54d0 Cut mutton into 1 inch (25 mm) pieces. Mix with salt, pepper and garlic.
c15bc6a2-e898-4943-b794-4be0db5f54d0 Place pork bones in pot, cover with 600 ml (20 oz) water and boil for 4 hours. Strain the stock.
c15bc6a2-e898-4943-b794-4be0db5f54d0 Making the roux. Heat the lard in a frying pan, adding flour. Stir continuously until light brown. Add 160 ml (2/3 cup) of pork stock (leftover liquid from boiling bones) and mix together. Add vinegar and mix.
c15bc6a2-e898-4943-b794-4be0db5f54d0 Mix diced meats, ground skins, diced onion, spices and the roux together.
c15bc6a2-e898-4943-b794-4be0db5f54d0 a. Pack about 160 g meat (5.64 oz) and cover with roux-stock liquid. Add about 200 g (7.05 oz) beans into pint jars. Fill with hot boiling stock leaving 1 inch headspace. b. Pack about 100 g of meat (3.52 oz) and cover with roux-stock liquid. Add about 120 g (4.23 oz) of beans. Fill with hot boiling stock leaving 1 inch headspace.
c15bc6a2-e898-4943-b794-4be0db5f54d0 Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process at once at 250° F, 121° C: 1/2 Pint jars - 50 min Pint jars - 60 min
67ff38f7-9ae1-488f-b0eb-b629cda6c573 Cut mutton into 1 inch (25 mm) pieces.
67ff38f7-9ae1-488f-b0eb-b629cda6c573 Fry meat pieces in lard until medium cooked.
67ff38f7-9ae1-488f-b0eb-b629cda6c573 Remove meat pieces and mix with salt, spices and tomato sauce. Save the meat sauce.
67ff38f7-9ae1-488f-b0eb-b629cda6c573 Place pork bones in pot, cover with 1 liter (1 quart) of water and boil for 4 hours. Strain the stock. Add meat sauce (from frying meat) and mix with pork stock.
67ff38f7-9ae1-488f-b0eb-b629cda6c573 Wash the raw rice.
67ff38f7-9ae1-488f-b0eb-b629cda6c573 Pack about 140 g meat (5 oz) and 100 g (3.5 oz) of rice into pint jars. Fill with hot boiling stock leaving 1 inch headspace. Pack about 85 g of meat (3 oz) and 50 g (1.76 oz) of rice. Fill with hot boiling stock leaving 1 inch headspace.
67ff38f7-9ae1-488f-b0eb-b629cda6c573 Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process at once at 150° F, 121° C: 1/2 Pint jars - 40 min Pint jars - 50 min
333dc0ed-8ecd-48c7-9c44-6d828d45adc2 NOTE there is no thermal processing involved.
333dc0ed-8ecd-48c7-9c44-6d828d45adc2 There were very few products that were not submitted to thermal process. The products were lard and smoked bacon, both packed in cans. Smoked sausages were often packed in lard to extend their shelf life. The practice was not limited to Eastern European countries, but was common in other areas, for example in Cuba. Such products were kept in root cellars or in cool pantries. Fresh fat is a poor medium for bacteria to grow as it contains very few nutrients and little moisture (15%) as compared to meat which contains proteins, vitamins, minerals and 75% moisture. During production of lard most of the moisture is evaporated during heating and this is the reason lard keeps so well.
333dc0ed-8ecd-48c7-9c44-6d828d45adc2 Dice back fat into 1/4 inch cubes or grind through a 3/8" plate.
333dc0ed-8ecd-48c7-9c44-6d828d45adc2 Put skillet on a heat source and add diced/ground back fat. Apply heat and start melting the fat, stirring often. Any indication of smoke signifies that the temperature is too high, turn the heat down.
333dc0ed-8ecd-48c7-9c44-6d828d45adc2 Remove cracklings by filtering the lard through a strainer.
333dc0ed-8ecd-48c7-9c44-6d828d45adc2 When the temperature of the lard drops to 72° F, 22° C, pour the lard into No. 2.5, 401 x 411 or No. 2, 307 x 409 cans. Place in a cool area so the lard will set. If needed, you can add more warm (liquid) lard to the container.
333dc0ed-8ecd-48c7-9c44-6d828d45adc2 Seal the cans.
333dc0ed-8ecd-48c7-9c44-6d828d45adc2 Clean the cans and store.
5bae5bbe-5947-4b0b-963e-b197ebbc3a38 Grind back fat through 1/4" (5 mm) plate adding salt.
5bae5bbe-5947-4b0b-963e-b197ebbc3a38 Mix the ground fat to distribute uniformly salt.
5bae5bbe-5947-4b0b-963e-b197ebbc3a38 Warm up the fat slightly (100° F, 38° C) then pour into warm jars leaving 1 inch headspace.
5bae5bbe-5947-4b0b-963e-b197ebbc3a38 Process without delay at 250° F, 121° C: 1/2 Pint jar - 50 min Pint jar - 60 min
64e9b2e6-9c59-49e1-b1c1-02088c879f9c Dice fresh garlic finely, then mix/grind with a small amount of salt. Use a spoon and the cup or mortar and pestle for that purpose.
64e9b2e6-9c59-49e1-b1c1-02088c879f9c Grind fresh back fat and smoked back fat together through 1/4" (5-6 mm) plate adding all ingredients.
64e9b2e6-9c59-49e1-b1c1-02088c879f9c Remix ground fat to distribute uniformly the ingredients.
64e9b2e6-9c59-49e1-b1c1-02088c879f9c Warm up the fat slightly (100° F, 38° C) then pour into warm jars leaving 1 inch headspace.
64e9b2e6-9c59-49e1-b1c1-02088c879f9c Process without delay at 250° F, 121° C: 1/2 Pint jar - 50 min Pint jar - 60 min
f67551c5-e93b-4c76-8383-d397d163fbb0 Peel the onions, slice into discs and fry in fat until golden (don't brown them).
f67551c5-e93b-4c76-8383-d397d163fbb0 Grind back fat through 1/4" (5-6 mm) plate together with salt and onion.
f67551c5-e93b-4c76-8383-d397d163fbb0 Mix the ground fat to distribute uniformly the ingredients.
f67551c5-e93b-4c76-8383-d397d163fbb0 Warm up the fat slightly (100° F, 38° C) then pour into warm jars leaving 1 inch headspace.
f67551c5-e93b-4c76-8383-d397d163fbb0 Process without delay at 250° F, 121° C: 1/2 Pint jar - 50 min Pint jar - 60 min
9ea7fef8-7929-43e1-b836-ffd2e5174cff NOTE * Potato flour binds water well. It also inhibits jelly formation which children usually don't like to eat.
9ea7fef8-7929-43e1-b836-ffd2e5174cff Curing mix. Mix salt with cure #1
9ea7fef8-7929-43e1-b836-ffd2e5174cff Cut all meat into 1 inch pieces, but keep both meat grades in separate containers.
9ea7fef8-7929-43e1-b836-ffd2e5174cff Mix pork grade I with ? of curing mix. Mix pork grade III with ? of curing mix. Pack tightly in separate containers and cover meat with a clean cloth.
9ea7fef8-7929-43e1-b836-ffd2e5174cff Cure for 72 hours in refrigerator.
9ea7fef8-7929-43e1-b836-ffd2e5174cff Grind pork grade III through ?" (3 mm) plate.
9ea7fef8-7929-43e1-b836-ffd2e5174cff Mix (knead) pork grade I until it becomes sticky. During mixing start adding potato flour. When meat is thoroughly mixed with the flour, add 30 ml of cold water and remix all together.
9ea7fef8-7929-43e1-b836-ffd2e5174cff Fill cans leaving º inch headspace.
9ea7fef8-7929-43e1-b836-ffd2e5174cff Exhaust cans to 170° F, 77° C meat temperature.
9ea7fef8-7929-43e1-b836-ffd2e5174cff Process at once at 250° F, 121° C: No.2, 307x409 - 80 min
ce9024f9-985e-46bf-bf99-6ca5616f06ae Cut pork into 1" (25 mm) pieces.
ce9024f9-985e-46bf-bf99-6ca5616f06ae Simmer the skins with bay leaf for 25 minutes at 194-203° F, 90-95° C, until semi-soft, then strain and place on screen/table to drain and cool. Save the liquid.
ce9024f9-985e-46bf-bf99-6ca5616f06ae Grind the skins through 1/8" (3 mm) plate.
ce9024f9-985e-46bf-bf99-6ca5616f06ae Making the roux. Heat the lard in a frying pan, adding flour. Stir continuously until light brown. Add 160 ml (2/3 cup) of cold skin stock (leftover liquid from boiling skins) and mix together.
ce9024f9-985e-46bf-bf99-6ca5616f06ae Mix diced meats, ground skins, diced onion, spices and the roux together.
ce9024f9-985e-46bf-bf99-6ca5616f06ae Pack the cans, leaving 1/2" headspace.
ce9024f9-985e-46bf-bf99-6ca5616f06ae Exhaust cans to 170° F, 77° C meat temperature and remove air bubbles.
ce9024f9-985e-46bf-bf99-6ca5616f06ae Fill the cans with hot boiling skin stock to 1/4" from top.
ce9024f9-985e-46bf-bf99-6ca5616f06ae Process at once at 240° F, 116° C: No.1 (picnic), 211x400 - 55 min.
a8f6e348-1d5b-400f-a273-fcf13cef9d77 Beef: Saw or crack fresh trimmed beef bones to enhance extraction of flavor. Rinse bones and place in a large stockpot or kettle, cover bones with water, add pot cover, and simmer 3 to 4 hours. Remove bones, cool broth, and pick off meat. Skim off fat, add meat trimmings removed from bones to broth, and reheat to boiling. Fill hot jars, leaving 1 inch headspace. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
a8f6e348-1d5b-400f-a273-fcf13cef9d77 Chicken or turkey: Place large carcass bones (with most of meat removed) in a large stock pot, add enough water to cover bones, cover pot, and simmer 30 to 45 minutes or until remaining attached meat can be easily stripped from bones. Remove bones and pieces, cool broth, strip meat, discard excess fat, and return meat trimmings to broth. Reheat to boiling and fill jars, leaving 1 inch headspace. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
a8f6e348-1d5b-400f-a273-fcf13cef9d77 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
a8f6e348-1d5b-400f-a273-fcf13cef9d77 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
fd3ea45d-c394-425e-bc53-3f820ad1cd87 Combine ingredients. Yield is 7 quarts or 16 pints.
fd3ea45d-c394-425e-bc53-3f820ad1cd87 Glass jars. Fill jars to top with raw meat-vegetable mixture. Add salt if desired: 1/2 teaspoon per pint or 1 teaspoon per quart. Adjust lids and process at once at 10 pounds pressure (240° F).
fd3ea45d-c394-425e-bc53-3f820ad1cd87 Metal cans. Fill cans to top with raw meat-vegetable mixture. Do not add liquid. Add salt if desired: 1/2 teaspoon to No. 2 cans or 1 teaspoon to No. 2.5 cans. To exhaust air, cook stew at slow boil to 170° F., or until medium done (about 50 minutes). Seal cans and process at once at 10 pounds pressure (240° F).
fd3ea45d-c394-425e-bc53-3f820ad1cd87 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
c27a874a-8018-45b5-8736-b3085f15c22a Wash the liver, cut it across and then scald in hot water (167° F, 75° C) until no more blood is released.
c27a874a-8018-45b5-8736-b3085f15c22a Wash the skins and feet meat. Simmer in water (194° F, 90° C) for two hours.
c27a874a-8018-45b5-8736-b3085f15c22a Simmer all pork and fat trimmings with 1/2 bay leaf in a little water (194° F, 90° C) for about 30 minutes.
c27a874a-8018-45b5-8736-b3085f15c22a Drain and leave on the screen/table to cool down.
c27a874a-8018-45b5-8736-b3085f15c22a Cut the onion in discs and fry in fat until golden.
c27a874a-8018-45b5-8736-b3085f15c22a Grind liver, meat, fat trimmings and onion through 1/8" (3 mm) plate. Add all spices and either grind again or process in food processor, until one smooth paste is obtained.
c27a874a-8018-45b5-8736-b3085f15c22a Pack into glass jars leaving 1 inch headspace.
c27a874a-8018-45b5-8736-b3085f15c22a Place jars into warm water and heat up to about 100° F, 38° C.
c27a874a-8018-45b5-8736-b3085f15c22a Seal jars, and process at once at 250° F, 121° C: 1/2 Pint - 50 min Pint - 60 min
0dfa4ab9-cc43-40c2-88e7-18f3c36c688f Continue after step 4:
0dfa4ab9-cc43-40c2-88e7-18f3c36c688f Wash the liver, cut it across and then scald it in hot water (167° F, 75° C) until no more blood is released.
0dfa4ab9-cc43-40c2-88e7-18f3c36c688f Dice onion, take 10 g of fat trimmings and fry onion until golden.
0dfa4ab9-cc43-40c2-88e7-18f3c36c688f Precook all meats and fat trimmings (except liver) in a skillet, stirring often, until meat looses its raw meat color.
0dfa4ab9-cc43-40c2-88e7-18f3c36c688f Grind liver, meat and fat trimmings through 1/8" (3 mm) plate or smaller. Add all spices and either grind again or process in food processor, until one smooth paste is obtained.
0dfa4ab9-cc43-40c2-88e7-18f3c36c688f Pack into glass jars leaving 1 inch headspace.
0dfa4ab9-cc43-40c2-88e7-18f3c36c688f Place jars into warm water and heat up to about 100° F, 38° C.
0dfa4ab9-cc43-40c2-88e7-18f3c36c688f Seal jars, and process at once at 250° F, 121° C: 1/2 Pint - 50 min Pint - 60 min
2589d490-db5e-4b14-9ecf-788156515108 Dry cure mix. Mix salt with cure #1.
2589d490-db5e-4b14-9ecf-788156515108 Cut pork grade I into 1 inch pieces. Add 1/3 of dry cure mix during grinding. Grind pork grade II through 1/2" (12 mm) plate. Add 1/3 of dry cure mix during grinding. Grind pork grade III through 1/8 plate (3 mm). Add 1/3 tsp of dry cure mix during grinding. Re-grind again adding 6 ml (1 tsp) of water.
2589d490-db5e-4b14-9ecf-788156515108 Mix all meats together adding pepper. When the mixture feels sticky add gradually potato flour and keep on mixing.
2589d490-db5e-4b14-9ecf-788156515108 Pack cans with about 425 g (15 oz) leaving 1/4 inch headspace.
2589d490-db5e-4b14-9ecf-788156515108 Exhaust cans to 170° F, 77° C meat temperature.
2589d490-db5e-4b14-9ecf-788156515108 Process at once at 240° F, 116° C: 301x408 - 55 min
093873a8-8347-4b10-bfd8-9f0e88859f80 Steps 1-4 remain the same.
093873a8-8347-4b10-bfd8-9f0e88859f80 Curing solution 14 Be, 55° SAL. Dissolve 1.15 lb (523 g) of salt in 1 gallon of cold water. Add 120 g (4.2 oz) of cure #1 (there is 112 g of salt in cure #1 and it is included in the calculation).
093873a8-8347-4b10-bfd8-9f0e88859f80 Remove bones from hocks using as few cuts as possible. Using meat pump inject each meat cut with curing solution. Place pumped meats in a container and fill with curing solution. Use 60% solution to 40% of meat by weight, for example: 400 g of meat and 600 ml solution. Cure for 48-72 hours in refrigerator. Place for 8 hours on screens to drain at refrigerator temperature (40° F, 4° C).
093873a8-8347-4b10-bfd8-9f0e88859f80 Simmer meats at 194-203° F, 90-95° C for 30 minutes. Cut meat to smaller pieces, about 120 g (4 oz).
093873a8-8347-4b10-bfd8-9f0e88859f80 Dissolve commercial gelatin in cold water, then bring to a boil adding bay leaf and Maggi liquid seasoning. Simmer for 30 minutes.
093873a8-8347-4b10-bfd8-9f0e88859f80 Pack 2-3 pieces of meat, about 400 g (14 oz) total weight into pint jar, add a few mustard seeds and a piece of bay leaf. Pack 1-2 pieces of meat, about 200 g (7 oz) into 1/2 pint jar, adding a few mustard seeds and a part of bay leaf. Pour hot gelatin solution, leave 1 inch headspace, remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process at once at 250° F, 121° C: 1/2 Pint Jar - 30 min Pint jar - 40 min
093873a8-8347-4b10-bfd8-9f0e88859f80 No. 2.5 can, 401 x 411: Pack 800 g meat (28.22 oz) and fill 75 ml (2.5 oz) gelatin solution. Add 12 mustard seeds. 301 x 408 can: Pack 400 g meat (14.11 oz) and fill with 30 ml (1 oz) gelatin solution. Add 6 mustard seeds. Pack cans leaving 1/2 inch headspace.
093873a8-8347-4b10-bfd8-9f0e88859f80 Exhaust cans to 170° F, 77° C meat temperature. Remove air bubbles. Add hot gelatin solution to 1/4 from top.
093873a8-8347-4b10-bfd8-9f0e88859f80 Seal and process at once at 250° F, 121° C: 301x408 - 60 min 401x411 - 75 min
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 The final product consists from pieces of meat bound together with natural gelatin. When kept cold, it should remain in one piece.
1bde1426-569a-446f-8ae1-20f029b8cbdb Soak beans for 12 hours in water. Stir. Dry beans must gain 80% in weight (use scale). If more weight gain is needed soak beans longer. Scald soaked beans in boiled water for 3 minutes. Drain and spread on table to cool.
1bde1426-569a-446f-8ae1-20f029b8cbdb Cut pork grade II into 1 inch (25 mm) pieces. Grind pork grade III through 1/8" (3 mm) plate.
1bde1426-569a-446f-8ae1-20f029b8cbdb Mix ground pork grade III with 6 g salt (1 tsp), then add pieces of pork grade II, 12 g salt (2 tsp) and keep on mixing until sticky. Add potato flour and remix.
1bde1426-569a-446f-8ae1-20f029b8cbdb Making roux. Heat the lard in a frying pan, adding flour. Stir continuously until light brown.
1bde1426-569a-446f-8ae1-20f029b8cbdb Sauce. Add to roux one pint (373 ml) of tomato sauce and mix together. Add all spices, Maggi, vinegar and bring to a boil, stirring often. Turn the heat off.
1bde1426-569a-446f-8ae1-20f029b8cbdb Pack cans with 70 g (2.47 oz) meat mass, add 80 (2.82) g soaked and scalded beans and fill with sauce leaving 1/2 inch headspace.
1bde1426-569a-446f-8ae1-20f029b8cbdb Exhaust cans to 170° F, 77° C meat temperature. Fill with hot sauce to 1/4 inch from top.
1bde1426-569a-446f-8ae1-20f029b8cbdb Seal and process at once at 250° F, 121° C: 307x200.25 can - 45 min
086b5ab9-26d1-47cb-bf0f-a7d32b1a81b2 Choose freshly killed and dressed, healthy animals. Large chickens are more flavorful than fryers. Dressed chicken should be chilled for 6 to 12 hours before canning. Remove excess fat. Cut the meat into suitable sizes for canning. Can with or without bones. Strong flavored game birds like water fowl may be soaked for 1 hour in a brine made from 1 tablespoon salt and 1 quart of water. If you soak game birds, donít add salt when packing jars.
086b5ab9-26d1-47cb-bf0f-a7d32b1a81b2 Chicken-Duck-Goose-Turkey & Game Birds.
086b5ab9-26d1-47cb-bf0f-a7d32b1a81b2 Hot Pack - Boil, steam, or bake meat until about two-thirds done. Add 1 tsp salt per quart, 1/2 tsp per pint, if desired. Fill hot jars with pieces and hot broth, leaving 1º inch headspace. Remove air bubbles.
086b5ab9-26d1-47cb-bf0f-a7d32b1a81b2 Raw Pack - Add 1 tsp salt per quart, 1/2 tsp per pint if desired. Fill hot jars loosely with raw meat pieces, leaving 1º inch headspace. Do not add liquid. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
086b5ab9-26d1-47cb-bf0f-a7d32b1a81b2 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
086b5ab9-26d1-47cb-bf0f-a7d32b1a81b2 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
375a522f-b4ed-4767-8496-e6b461d2dd29 Cut rabbit into suitable sizes for canning. Soak meat for 1 hour in water containing 1 tablespoon of salt per quart, and rinse. Prepare the meaty pieces, with or without bones, and pack and process as for poultry, omitting the salt.
375a522f-b4ed-4767-8496-e6b461d2dd29 Hot Pack - Boil, steam, or bake meat until about two-thirds done. Add 1 tsp salt per quart, 1/2 tsp per pint, if desired. Fill hot jars with pieces and hot broth, leaving 1º inch headspace. Remove air bubbles.
375a522f-b4ed-4767-8496-e6b461d2dd29 Raw pack - Add 1 tsp salt per quart, 1/2 tsp per pint if desired. Fill hot jars loosely with raw meat pieces, leaving 1-1/4 inch headspace. Do not add liquid. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
375a522f-b4ed-4767-8496-e6b461d2dd29 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
375a522f-b4ed-4767-8496-e6b461d2dd29 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 Any good sausage recipe may be used. It is best to go easy on the spices because of flavor changes which may develop during canning and storing. Mold sausage into smooth, round flat cakes. Precook, pack and process the same as hamburger, hot pack. The following recipe for sausage is suggested:
427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 For four pounds ground pork use:
427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 For 100 pounds ground pork use:
427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c Do not increase the proportion of onions, peppers, or mushrooms.
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
f4e1b8c4-a5be-4b59-935e-e8bcd563eb1e Soak meat for 1 hour in water containing 1 tablespoon of salt per quart, and then rinse. Use processing times for poultry, omitting the salt.
f4e1b8c4-a5be-4b59-935e-e8bcd563eb1e Hot Pack - Boil, steam, or bake meat until about two-thirds done. Add 1 tsp salt per quart, 1/2 tsp per pint, if desired. Fill hot jars with pieces and hot broth, leaving 1-1/4 inch headspace. Remove air bubbles.
f4e1b8c4-a5be-4b59-935e-e8bcd563eb1e Raw Pack - Add 1 tsp salt per quart, 1/2 tsp per pint if desired. Fill hot jars loosely with raw meat pieces, leaving 1-1/4 inch headspace. Do not add liquid. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
f4e1b8c4-a5be-4b59-935e-e8bcd563eb1e For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
f4e1b8c4-a5be-4b59-935e-e8bcd563eb1e For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
12d60c30-643d-4be2-a67c-5798c7da0fdb Choose quality chilled meat. Remove excess fat. Soak strong-flavored wild meats for 1 hour in brine water containing 1 tablespoon of salt per quart of water. Rinse. Remove large bones.
12d60c30-643d-4be2-a67c-5798c7da0fdb Bear, beef, lamb, pork, veal, venison.
12d60c30-643d-4be2-a67c-5798c7da0fdb Hot Pack - Precook meat until rare by roasting, stewing, or browning in a small amount of fat. Add 1 teaspoon of salt per quart to the jar, 1/2 teaspoon to pints, if desired. Fill hot jars with pieces and add boiling broth, meat drippings, water, or tomato juice (especially with wild game), leaving 1 inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and wipe jar rims.
12d60c30-643d-4be2-a67c-5798c7da0fdb Raw Pack - Add 1 teaspoon of salt per quart to the jar, 1/2 teaspoon to pints, if desired. Pack raw meat in hot jars, leaving 1 inch headspace. Do not add liquid. Wipe rims of jars. Adjust lids and process.
12d60c30-643d-4be2-a67c-5798c7da0fdb For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
12d60c30-643d-4be2-a67c-5798c7da0fdb For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
78e3a73c-8233-4f12-b50a-b60b6616108a Both beef and pork stomachs are prepared in the same manner. Clean stomachs well, than soak for 12 hours in cold water. A few water changes are needed. Cur stomachs into two parts, place in water and bring to a boil. Cook for 15 minutes. Remove from water and check for a smell. If an odor is still detected, boil stomachs for additional 15 minutes and the odor will go away. Place stomachs on screens or tables to cool.
78e3a73c-8233-4f12-b50a-b60b6616108a Wash the skins and simmer at 194-203° F, 90-95° C for 60 minutes in about 120 ml (1/2 cup) of water. Spread on table to cool down.
78e3a73c-8233-4f12-b50a-b60b6616108a Place bones in pot, add 5 liters (5 quarts and one cup) of water and bring to a boil. Cook for 3 hours, add parsley, celery and carrots and cook one more hour (total 4 hours). Strain the stock.
78e3a73c-8233-4f12-b50a-b60b6616108a Cut stomachs into strips 2 x 1/4" (50 x 6 mm). Grind skins through 1/8" (3 mm) plate.
78e3a73c-8233-4f12-b50a-b60b6616108a Mix tripe (stomach strips) with ground skins adding salt, remaining spices and melted lard.
78e3a73c-8233-4f12-b50a-b60b6616108a Place 280 g (10 oz) tripe mixture in pint jar, and 140 g (5 oz) tripe in 1/2 pint jars. Add boiling hot beef stock leaving 1 inch headspace.
78e3a73c-8233-4f12-b50a-b60b6616108a Process at once at 250° F, 121° C: 1/2 Pint jars - 50 min Pint jars - 60 min
955dd18a-54c0-4e35-a94f-622c0fc7fe00 Both beef and pork stomachs are prepared in the same manner. Clean stomachs well, than soak for 12 hours in cold water. A few water changes are needed. Cur stomachs into two parts, place in water and bring to a boil. Cook for 15 minutes. Remove from water and check for a smell. If an odor is still detected, boil stomachs for additional 15 minutes and the odor will go away. Place stomachs on screens or tables to cool.
955dd18a-54c0-4e35-a94f-622c0fc7fe00 Wash the skins and simmer at 194-203° F, 90-95° C for 60 minutes in about 120 ml (1/2 cup) of water. Spread on table to cool down. Grind through 1/8" (3 mm) plate or smaller.
955dd18a-54c0-4e35-a94f-622c0fc7fe00 Place bones in pot, add 5 liters (5 quarts and one cup) of water and bring to a boil. Cook for 3 hours, add parsley, celery and carrots and cook one more hour (total 4 hours). Strain the stock.
955dd18a-54c0-4e35-a94f-622c0fc7fe00 Cut stomachs into strips 2 x 1/4" (50 x 6 mm). Grind skins through 1/8" (3 mm) plate. Mix the tripe and ground skins together adding salt, remaining spices and melted lard.
955dd18a-54c0-4e35-a94f-622c0fc7fe00 Place 280 g (10 oz) tripe mixture in pint jar, and 140 g (5 oz) tripe in 1/2 pint jars. Add boiling hot beef stock leaving 1 inch headspace.
955dd18a-54c0-4e35-a94f-622c0fc7fe00 Process at once at 250° F, 121° C: 1/2 Pint jars - 40 min Pint jars - 60 min
f180143e-ef7d-41c9-8f83-9972d00eac13 Whole or minced.
f180143e-ef7d-41c9-8f83-9972d00eac13 Hot Pack - keep clams live on ice until ready to can. Scrub shells thoroughly and rinse, steam 5 minutes, and open. Remove clam meat. Collect and save clam juice. Wash clam meat in water containing 1 teaspoon of salt per quart. Rinse and cover clam meat with boiling water containing 2 tablespoons of lemon juice or 1/2 teaspoon of citric acid per gallon. Boil 2 minutes and drain. To make minced clams, grind clams with a meat grinder or food processor. Fill hot jars loosely with pieces and add hot clam juice and boiling water if needed, leaving 1 inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
f180143e-ef7d-41c9-8f83-9972d00eac13 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
ffcecd10-919b-4711-afe1-4b70a9b11b88 Use fillets and all fish meat that can be scraped off the bones.
ffcecd10-919b-4711-afe1-4b70a9b11b88 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
f4059d55-f73c-4440-a2e0-ab96573dbce4 If the fish is frozen, thaw it in the refrigerator before canning. Rinse the fish in cold water. You can add vinegar to the water (2 tablespoons per quart) to help remove slime. Remove head, tail, fins, and scales; it is not necessary to remove the skin. You can leave the bones in most fish because the bones become very soft and are a good source of calcium. For halibut, remove the head, tail, fins, skin, and the bones. Wash and remove all blood. Refrigerate all fish until you are ready to pack in jars. Split fish lengthwise, if desired. Cut cleaned fish into 3-1/2-inch lengths. If the skin has been left on the fish, pack the fish skin out, for a nicer appearance or skin in, for easier jar cleaning. Fill hot pint jars, leaving 1-inch headspace. Add 1 teaspoon of salt per pint, if desired. Do not add liquids. Carefully clean the jar rims with a clean, damp paper towel; wipe with a dry paper towel to remove any fish oil. Adjust lids and process. Fish in half-pint or 12-ounce jars would be processed for the same amount of time as pint jars.
f4059d55-f73c-4440-a2e0-ab96573dbce4 Blue, mackerel, salmon, steelhead, trout, and other fatty fish except tuna.
f4059d55-f73c-4440-a2e0-ab96573dbce4 CAUTION Bleed and eviscerate fish immediately after catching, never more than 2 hours after they are caught. Keep cleaned fish on ice until ready to can.
f4059d55-f73c-4440-a2e0-ab96573dbce4 NOTE Glass-like crystals of struvite, or magnesium ammonium phosphate, sometime form in canned salmon. There is no way for the home canner to prevent these crystals from forming, but they usually dissolve when heated and are safe to eat.
f4059d55-f73c-4440-a2e0-ab96573dbce4 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
4c308600-c575-4cbe-9df8-01c46b225f55 If the fish is frozen, thaw it in the refrigerator before canning. Rinse the fish in cold water. You can add vinegar to the water (2 tablespoons per quart) to help remove slime. Remove head, tail, fins, and scales; it is not necessary to remove the skin. You can leave the bones in most fish because the bones become very soft and are a good source of calcium. For halibut, remove the head, tail, fins, skin, and the bones. Wash and remove all blood. Refrigerate all fish until you are ready to pack in jars. Cut the fish into jar-length filets or chunks of any size. The one-quart straight-sided mason type jar is recommended. If the skin has been left on the fish, pack the fish skin out, for a nicer appearance or skin in, for easier jar cleaning. Pack solidly into hot quart jars, leaving 1 inch headspace. If desired, run a plastic knife around the inside of the jar to align the product; this allows firm packing of fish. For most fish, no liquid, salt, or spices need to be added, although seasonings or salt may be added for flavor (1 to 2 teaspoons salt per quart, or amount desired). For halibut, add up to 4 tablespoons of vegetable or olive oil per quart jar if you wish. The canned product will seem moister. However, the oil will increase the caloric value of the fish. Carefully clean the jar rims with a clean, damp paper towel; wipe with a dry paper towel to remove any fish oil. Adjust lids and process.
4c308600-c575-4cbe-9df8-01c46b225f55 The directions for operating the pressure canner during processing of quart jars are different from those for processing pint jars, so please read the following carefully. It is critical to product safety that the processing directions are followed exactly. When you are ready to process your jars of fish, add 3 quarts of water to the pressure canner. Put the rack in the bottom of canner and place closed jars on the rack. Fasten the canner cover securely, but do not close the lid vent. Heat the canner on high for 20 minutes. If steam comes through the open vent in a steady stream at the end of 20 minutes, allow it to escape for an additional 10 minutes. If steam does not come through the open vent in a steady stream at the end of 20 minutes, keep heating the canner until it does. Then allow the steam to escape for an additional 10 minutes to vent the canner. This step removes air from inside the canner so the temperature is the same throughout the canner. The total time it takes to heat and vent the canner should never be less than 30 minutes. The total time may be more than 30 minutes if you have tightly packed jars, cold fish, or larger sized canners. For safety's sake, you must have a complete, uninterrupted 160 minutes (2 hours and 40 minutes) at a minimum pressure required for your altitude. Write down the time at the beginning of the process and the time when the process will be finished.
4c308600-c575-4cbe-9df8-01c46b225f55 Blue, mackerel, salmon, steelhead, trout, and other fatty fish except tuna.
4c308600-c575-4cbe-9df8-01c46b225f55 NOTE Glass-like crystals of struvite, or magnesium ammonium phosphate, sometime form in canned salmon. There is no way for the home canner to prevent these crystals from forming, but they usually dissolve when heated and are safe to eat.
4c308600-c575-4cbe-9df8-01c46b225f55 CAUTION Bleed and eviscerate fish immediately after catching, never more than 2 hours after they are caught. Keep cleaned fish on ice until ready to can.
4c308600-c575-4cbe-9df8-01c46b225f55 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
cecf139f-636d-4bd5-9783-f0ca2be2a59f Mullet, mackerel or other fish.
cecf139f-636d-4bd5-9783-f0ca2be2a59f Pack warm smoked fillets solidly into the jars. Fillets can be rolled before packing. Leave one inch of headspace between the fish and the top of the jar. Place 2-3 inches of warm water in the canner, and the rack and place the jars. Process at once.
cecf139f-636d-4bd5-9783-f0ca2be2a59f Exhaust. Place a suitable pot or pan on the stove with some hot water in it. Have more hot water nearby. Place warm smoked fillets solidly into cans. Leave one inch headspace. Place the open cans in the boiling water in a single layer. The water should come up halfway up the outside of the cans. Do not cover cans with the lids. Heat the uncovered pot until the fish reach a temperature of 170° F, 77° C. Covering the pot will result in moisture dripping into the cans. Remove cans from the pot and seal. Process at once.
cecf139f-636d-4bd5-9783-f0ca2be2a59f For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
cecf139f-636d-4bd5-9783-f0ca2be2a59f NOTE no additional fat or oil is needed for canning oily fish like mullet, mackerel, salmon or herring. When canning lean fish, up to 2 tablespoons of olive/vegetable oil may be added to 1/2 pint jar or 1/2 lb can.
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 Cook all ingredients until reduced to about half the original volume. Put through a fine strainer. This sauce may be put over fish in the jars before processing or served with fresh cooked or plain canned fish.
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 Fish for canning should be strictly fresh. It is well to stick fish with a knife to drain out the blood as soon as they are caught. The viscera should also be removed as soon as possible.
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 Scale or wash carefully. Scales are easier to remove if fish are dipped into boiling water and then into cold water. If skins are tough, skin the fish.
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 In order to draw out the blood before canning, place fish in a brine made by using 1 tablespoon salt to each quart of water. Let fish soak 10 minutes to one hour, according to thickness. Small trout need only 10 minutes soaking. This soaking is not absolutely essential but makes for a better looking product. It tends to make fish firmer.
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 Remove from brine, wash and drain on clean towels.
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 Leave whole or cut into convenient, uniform pieces.
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 Season fish before frying if they were not soaked in brine.
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 Fry in deep fat till nicely browned. Drain and place on brown paper to remove excess fat.
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 Pack into clean hot jars. Add about 2 tablespoon hot liquid. Add hot tomato sauce if desired and in that case use glass jars or R-enameled cans.
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 Seal and process at once.
4ce8eb3f-c002-4f3a-84b6-d79b1283dff1 An excess quantity of fish caught in spring and summer may be canned for use in other seasons. Fish for canning must be strictly fresh. Fish deteriorates rapidly in quality and flavor, so quick work is essential for a high grade product.
4ce8eb3f-c002-4f3a-84b6-d79b1283dff1 Procedure:
4ce8eb3f-c002-4f3a-84b6-d79b1283dff1 NOTE Fish canned in this manner will resemble canned salmon in texture.
4ce8eb3f-c002-4f3a-84b6-d79b1283dff1 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
4ce8eb3f-c002-4f3a-84b6-d79b1283dff1 Fish for canning should be strictly fresh. It is well to stick fish with a knife to drain out the blood as soon as they are caught. The viscera should also be removed as soon as possible.
4ce8eb3f-c002-4f3a-84b6-d79b1283dff1 Scale or wash carefully. Scales are easier to remove if fish are dipped into boiling water and then into cold water. If skins are tough, skin the fish.
4ce8eb3f-c002-4f3a-84b6-d79b1283dff1 In order to draw out the blood before canning, place fish in a brine made by using 1 tablespoon salt to each quart of water. Let fish soak 10 minutes to one hour, according to thickness. Small trout need only 10 minutes soaking. This soaking is not absolutely essential but makes for a better looking product. It tends to make fish firmer.
4ce8eb3f-c002-4f3a-84b6-d79b1283dff1 Pack fish into clean hot jars or tin cans, packing in "up and down" or "circular" fashion to make a good looking jar. Large fish will need to be cut into convenient, uniform pieces.
4ce8eb3f-c002-4f3a-84b6-d79b1283dff1 Add 1 teaspoon salt per pint jar if fish have not been previously soaked in brine. Do not add water. Hot tomato sauce may be poured over the fish in the jars or enameled cans.
4ce8eb3f-c002-4f3a-84b6-d79b1283dff1 Exhaust tin cans till steaming hot. Seal and process at once.
6bed8a90-687a-4e63-a4ad-16433c6ba066 If smoked fish has been frozen, thaw in the refrigerator until no ice crystals remain before canning. If not done prior to smoking, cut fish into pieces that will fit vertically into pint canning jars, leaving 1 inch headspace. Pack smoked fish vertically into hot jars, leaving 1 inch headspace between the pieces and the top rim of the jar. The fish may be packed either loosely or tightly.
6bed8a90-687a-4e63-a4ad-16433c6ba066 Do not add liquid to the jars. Clean jar rims with a clean, damp paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
6bed8a90-687a-4e63-a4ad-16433c6ba066 The directions for filling the pressure canner for processing smoked fish are different than those for other pressure canning, so please read the following carefully. It is critical to product safety that the processing directions are followed exactly. When you are ready to process your jars of smoked fish, measure 4 quarts (16 cups) of cool tap water and pour into the pressure canner. (Note: The water level probably will reach the screw bands of pint jars.) Do not decrease the amount of water or heat the water before processing begins. Place prepared, closed jars on the rack in the bottom of the canner, and proceed as with usual pressure canning instructions.
6bed8a90-687a-4e63-a4ad-16433c6ba066 Salmon, rockfish and flatfish (sole, cod, flounder) and other fish.
6bed8a90-687a-4e63-a4ad-16433c6ba066 CAUTION Safe processing times for other smoked seafoods have not been determined. Those products should be frozen. Smoking of fish should be done by tested methods. Lightly smoked fish is recommended for canning because the smoked flavor will become stronger and the flesh drier after processing. However, because it has not yet been cooked, do not taste lightly smoked fish before canning. Follow these recommended canning instructions carefully. Use a 16 to 22 quart pressure canner for this procedure; do not use smaller pressure saucepans. Safe processing times have not been determined. Do not use jars larger than one pint. Half-pints could be safely processed for the same length of time as pints, but the quality of the product may be less acceptable.
6bed8a90-687a-4e63-a4ad-16433c6ba066 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
6bed8a90-687a-4e63-a4ad-16433c6ba066 All fish can be smoked but the oily fish such as salmon, trout, herring, mackerel, eel, blue fish, and mullet taste the best.
ee2c91bd-600d-4ecc-a278-2e51c9e3fd36 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
19fc2890-a66f-44a1-afa2-5210ba8e712a Keep live crabs on ice until ready to can. Wash crabs thoroughly, using several changes of cold water. Simmer crabs 20 minutes in water containing cup of lemon juice and 2 tablespoons of salt (or up to 1 cup of salt, if desired) per gallon. Cool in cold water, drain, remove back shell, then remove meat from body and claws. Soak meat 2 minutes in cold water containing 2 cups of lemon juice or 4 cups of white vinegar, and 2 tablespoons of salt (or up to 1 cup of salt, if desired) per gallon. Drain and squeeze crab meat to remove excess moisture. Fill hot half-pint jars with 6 ounces of crab meat and pint jars with 12 ounces, leaving 1 inch headspace. Add Ω teaspoon of citric acid or 2 tablespoons of lemon juice to each half-pint jar, or 1 teaspoon of citric acid or 4 tablespoons of lemon juice per pint jar. Cover with fresh boiling water, leaving 1 inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
19fc2890-a66f-44a1-afa2-5210ba8e712a It is recommended that blue crab meat be frozen instead of canned for best quality. Crab meat canned according to the following procedure may have a distinctly acidic flavor and freezing is the preferred method of preservation at this time.
19fc2890-a66f-44a1-afa2-5210ba8e712a For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
3f44a8db-0353-4b61-8de7-3eae587607af Keep live oysters on ice until ready to can. Wash shells. Heat 5 to 7 minutes in preheated oven at 400° F (204° C). Cool briefly in ice water. Drain, open shell, and remove meat. Wash meat in water containing Ω cup salt per gallon. Drain. Add Ω teaspoon salt to each pint, if desired. Fill hot half-pint or pint jars with drained oysters and cover with fresh boiling water, leaving 1 inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
3f44a8db-0353-4b61-8de7-3eae587607af For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
1eed4e09-ee9d-4a6e-8816-0798c7fe8dcb For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
f90d0b4c-f049-4d33-b6d0-72cd3634f48a Keep tuna on ice until ready to can. Remove viscera and wash fish well in cold water. Allow blood to drain from stomach cavity. Place fish belly down on a rack or metal tray in the bottom of a large baking pan. Cut tuna in half crosswise, if necessary. Precook fish by baking at 250° F (121° C) for 2-1/2 to 4 hours (depending on size) or at 350° F (177° C) for 1 hour. The fish may also be cooked in a steamer for 2 to 4 hours. If a thermometer is used, cook to a 165° to 175° F (74 - 80° C) internal temperature. Refrigerate cooked fish overnight to firm the meat. Peel off the skin with a knife, removing blood vessels and any discolored flesh. Cut meat away from bones; cut out and discard all bones, fin bases, and dark flesh. Quarter. Cut quarters crosswise into lengths suitable for half-pint or pint jars. Fill into hot jars, pressing down gently to make a solid pack. Tuna may be packed in water or oil, whichever is preferred. Add water or oil to jars, leaving 1 inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt per half-pint or 1 teaspoon of salt per pint, if desired. Carefully clean the jar rims with a clean, damp paper towel; wipe with a dry paper towel to remove any fish oil. Adjust lids and process.
f90d0b4c-f049-4d33-b6d0-72cd3634f48a Tuna may be canned either precooked or raw. Precooking removes most of the strong-flavored oils. The strong flavor of dark tuna flesh affects the delicate flavor of white flesh. Many people prefer not to can dark flesh. It may be used as pet food.
f90d0b4c-f049-4d33-b6d0-72cd3634f48a NOTE glass-like crystals of struvite, or magnesium ammonium phosphate, sometime form in canned tuna. There is no way for the home canner to prevent these crystals from forming, but they usually dissolve when heated and are safe to eat.
f90d0b4c-f049-4d33-b6d0-72cd3634f48a For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustment.
c6ddf17c-3b79-4d28-b8f8-1c7c3dc14005 Wash asparagus and trim off tough scales. Break off tough stems and wash again. Cut into 1-inch pieces or can whole.
c6ddf17c-3b79-4d28-b8f8-1c7c3dc14005 Cover asparagus with boiling water. Boil 2 or 3 minutes. Loosely fill hot jars with hot asparagus, leaving 1-inch headspace.
c6ddf17c-3b79-4d28-b8f8-1c7c3dc14005 Fill hot jars with raw asparagus, packing as tightly as possible without crushing, leaving 1-inch headspace.
c6ddf17c-3b79-4d28-b8f8-1c7c3dc14005 Use tender, tight-tipped spears, 4 to 6 inches long.
c6ddf17c-3b79-4d28-b8f8-1c7c3dc14005 Add 1 teaspoon of salt per quart to the jars, if desired. Add boiling water, leaving 1-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
c6ddf17c-3b79-4d28-b8f8-1c7c3dc14005 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
7a524d6e-af23-49c1-ad1f-4925e33fd220 Procedure: Soak and boil beans and prepare molasses sauce.
7a524d6e-af23-49c1-ad1f-4925e33fd220 Molasses Sauce - Mix 4 cups water or cooking liquid from beans, 3 tablespoons dark molasses, 1 tablespoon vinegar, 2 teaspoons salt, and 3/4 teaspoon powered dry mustard. Heat to a boiling.
7a524d6e-af23-49c1-ad1f-4925e33fd220 Place seven 3/4-inch pieces of pork, ham, or bacon in an earthenware crock, a large casserole, or a pan. Add beans and enough molasses sauce to cover beans. Cover and bake 4 to 5 hours at 350° F, 177° C. Add water as needed-about every hour. Fill hot jars, leaving 1-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
7a524d6e-af23-49c1-ad1f-4925e33fd220 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
7a524d6e-af23-49c1-ad1f-4925e33fd220 NOTE the thermal process for beans in sauce depends in part upon the sauce formulation. Changing the sauce formula will affect the processing time.
ebd18e9e-e6b3-41aa-97ab-493622a2878d Place dried beans in a large pot and cover with water. Soak 12 to 18 hours in a cool place. Drain water. To quickly hydrate beans, you may cover sorted and washed beans with boiling water in a saucepan. Boil 2 minutes, remove from heat, soak 1 hour and drain. Cover beans soaked by either method with fresh water and boil 30 minutes.
ebd18e9e-e6b3-41aa-97ab-493622a2878d All varieties
ebd18e9e-e6b3-41aa-97ab-493622a2878d Select mature, dry seeds. Sort out and discard discolored seeds.
ebd18e9e-e6b3-41aa-97ab-493622a2878d Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt per pint or 1 teaspoon per quart to the jar, if desired. Fill hot jars with beans and cooking water, leaving 1-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
ebd18e9e-e6b3-41aa-97ab-493622a2878d For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
8704c893-17b0-42b3-9acf-091438ac3324 Sort and wash dry beans. Add 3 cups of water for each cup of dried beans or peas. Boil 2 minutes, remove from heat and soak 1 hour and drain. Heat to boiling in fresh water, and save liquid for making sauce. Make your choice of the following sauces:
8704c893-17b0-42b3-9acf-091438ac3324 Select mature, dry seeds. Sort out and discard discolored seeds.
8704c893-17b0-42b3-9acf-091438ac3324 Tomato Sauce 1 - Mix 1 quart tomato juice, 3 tablespoons sugar, 2 teaspoons salt, 1 tablespoon chopped onion, and 1/4 teaspoon each of ground cloves, allspice, mace, and cayenne pepper. Heat to boiling.
8704c893-17b0-42b3-9acf-091438ac3324 Tomato Sauce 2 - Mix 1 cup tomato ketchup with 3 cups of cooking liquid from beans. Heat to boiling.
8704c893-17b0-42b3-9acf-091438ac3324 Molasses Sauce - Mix 4 cups water or cooking liquid from beans, 3 tablespoons dark molasses, 1 tablespoon vinegar, 2 teaspoons salt, and 3/4 teaspoon powered dry mustard. Heat to boiling.
8704c893-17b0-42b3-9acf-091438ac3324 Fill hot jars three-fourths full with hot beans. Add one 3/4-inch cube of pork, ham, or bacon to each jar, if desired. Fill jars with heated sauce, leaving 1-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
8704c893-17b0-42b3-9acf-091438ac3324 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
8704c893-17b0-42b3-9acf-091438ac3324 NOTE the thermal process for beans in sauce depends in part upon the sauce formulation. Changing the sauce formula will affect the processing time. Do not add more meat or bacon.
bb6b1fd4-1fd3-4547-bf69-6e3784bc181d Shell beans and wash thoroughly.
bb6b1fd4-1fd3-4547-bf69-6e3784bc181d Cover beans with boiling water and heat to boil. Fill hot jars loosely, leaving 1-inch headspace. Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to pints, 1 teaspoon to quarts, if desired. Fill with boiling water to 1 inch from top. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
bb6b1fd4-1fd3-4547-bf69-6e3784bc181d Fill hot jars loosely with raw beans. Do not press or shake down.
bb6b1fd4-1fd3-4547-bf69-6e3784bc181d Select well-filled pods with green seeds. Discard insect-damaged and diseased seeds.
bb6b1fd4-1fd3-4547-bf69-6e3784bc181d Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to pints, 1 teaspoon to quarts, if desired. Add boiling water, leaving the same headspaces listed above. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
bb6b1fd4-1fd3-4547-bf69-6e3784bc181d For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
e3dbc624-d99c-4b24-a7b9-a9ea2ed64405 Wash beans and trim ends. Leave whole or cut or snap into 1-inch pieces.
e3dbc624-d99c-4b24-a7b9-a9ea2ed64405 Cover with boiling water; boil 5 minutes. Fill hot jars, loosely leaving 1-inch headspace. Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to pints, 1 teaspoon to quarts, if desired. Fill with boiling water to 1 inch from top. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
e3dbc624-d99c-4b24-a7b9-a9ea2ed64405 Fill hot jars tightly with raw beans, leaving 1-inch headspace.
e3dbc624-d99c-4b24-a7b9-a9ea2ed64405 Green and wax
e3dbc624-d99c-4b24-a7b9-a9ea2ed64405 Select filled but tender, crisp pods. Remove and discard diseased and rusty pods.
e3dbc624-d99c-4b24-a7b9-a9ea2ed64405 Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to pints, 1 teaspoon to quarts, if desired. Add boiling water, leaving 1-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
e3dbc624-d99c-4b24-a7b9-a9ea2ed64405 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
37a88ef1-b958-4fc6-8668-73a0e607c6fb Cut off beet tops, leaving an inch of stem and roots to reduce loss of color. Scrub well. Cover with boiling water. Boil until skins slip off easily; about 15 to 25 minutes depending on size. Cool, remove skins, and trim off stems and roots. Leave baby beets whole. Cut medium or large beets into 1/2-inch cubes or slices. Halve or quarter very large slices. Pack beets into hot jars leaving 1 inch headspace. Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to pints, 1 teaspoon to quarts, if desired. Fill jars with hot water to 1 inch from top. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
37a88ef1-b958-4fc6-8668-73a0e607c6fb Beets with a diameter of 1 to 2 inches are preferred for whole packs. Beets larger than 3 inches in diameter are often fibrous.
37a88ef1-b958-4fc6-8668-73a0e607c6fb For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
f6740b38-fccd-466f-91e4-f1ad361e1487 Wash, peel, and rewash carrots. Slice or dice.
f6740b38-fccd-466f-91e4-f1ad361e1487 Cover carrots with boiling water; bring to boil and simmer for 5 minutes. Fill hot jars, leaving 1-inch of headspace. Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to pints, 1 teaspoon to quarts, if desired. Fill jars with hot water to 1 inch from top.
f6740b38-fccd-466f-91e4-f1ad361e1487 Fill hot jars tightly with raw carrots, leaving 1-inch headspace.
f6740b38-fccd-466f-91e4-f1ad361e1487 Select small carrots, preferably 1 to 1-1/4 inches in diameter. Larger carrots are often too fibrous.
f6740b38-fccd-466f-91e4-f1ad361e1487 Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to pints, 1 teaspoon to quarts, if desired. Add hot cooking liquid or water, leaving 1-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
f6740b38-fccd-466f-91e4-f1ad361e1487 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
c370cce4-92ca-4fc7-a1bc-f8e972f121ef Husk corn, remove silk, and wash ears. Blanch ears 4 minutes in boiling water. Cut corn from cob at the center of kernel. Scrape remaining corn from cobs with a table knife.
c370cce4-92ca-4fc7-a1bc-f8e972f121ef Add 1 cup of boiling water to 2 cups of corn. Heat to a boil. Fill hot pint jar with hot corn, leaving 1-inch headspace. Add 1/2 teaspoon salt to each pint jar, if desired. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
c370cce4-92ca-4fc7-a1bc-f8e972f121ef Select ears containing slightly immature kernels, or of ideal quality for eating fresh.
c370cce4-92ca-4fc7-a1bc-f8e972f121ef For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
1bc5779f-0e4b-4bf5-81b7-aef9616fcaac Select ears containing slightly immature kernels or of ideal quality for eating fresh. Canning of some sweeter varieties or too immature kernels may cause browning. Can a small amount, check color and flavor before canning large quantities.
1bc5779f-0e4b-4bf5-81b7-aef9616fcaac Procedure: Husk corn, remove silk, and wash. Blanch 3 minutes in boiling water. Cut corn from cob at about 3/4 the depth of kernel.
1bc5779f-0e4b-4bf5-81b7-aef9616fcaac CAUTION Do not scrape cob.
1bc5779f-0e4b-4bf5-81b7-aef9616fcaac Hot Pack - To each clean quart of kernels in a saucepan, add 1 cup of hot water, heat to boiling and simmer 5 minutes. Fill hot jars with corn and cooking liquid, leaving 1-inch headspace. Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to pints, 1 teaspoon to quarts, if desired. Fill jars with hot water to 1 inch from top. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
1bc5779f-0e4b-4bf5-81b7-aef9616fcaac Raw Pack - Fill hot jars with corn, leaving 1-inch headspace. Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to pints, 1 teaspoon to quarts, if desired. Fill jars with hot water to 1 inch from top. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
1bc5779f-0e4b-4bf5-81b7-aef9616fcaac For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
c365ff8f-0295-4761-881a-62067c5ef4a2 Optional mix - You may change the suggested proportions or substitute other favorite vegetables except leafy greens, dried beans, cream-style corn, squash and sweet potatoes.
c365ff8f-0295-4761-881a-62067c5ef4a2 Procedure: Except for zucchini, wash and prepare vegetables for canning. Wash, trim, and slice or cube zucchini (if used); combine all vegetables in a large pot or kettle, and add enough water to cover pieces. Boil 5 minutes.
c365ff8f-0295-4761-881a-62067c5ef4a2 Hot Pack - fill hot jars with hot pieces, leaving 1-inch headspace. Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to pints, 1 teaspoon to quarts, if desired. Fill jars with hot water to 1 inch from top. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
c365ff8f-0295-4761-881a-62067c5ef4a2 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
cae9f47b-38ad-4d0e-8993-49a171f095f1 Select only brightly colored, small to medium-size domestic mushrooms with short stems, tight veils (unopened caps), and no discoloration.
cae9f47b-38ad-4d0e-8993-49a171f095f1 CAUTION Do not can wild mushrooms.
cae9f47b-38ad-4d0e-8993-49a171f095f1 Procedure: Trim stems and discolored parts. Soak in cold water for 10 minutes to remove dirt. Wash in clean water. Leave small mushrooms whole; cut large ones.
cae9f47b-38ad-4d0e-8993-49a171f095f1 Hot Pack - Cover with water in a saucepan and boil 5 minutes. Fill hot jars with hot mushrooms, leaving 1-inch headspace. Add 1/4 teaspoon of salt to half-pints, 1/2 teaspoon to pints, if desired. For better color, add 1/8 teaspoon of ascorbic acid powder, or a crushed 500-milligram tablet of vitamin C per pint. Fill jars with hot water to 1 inch from top. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
cae9f47b-38ad-4d0e-8993-49a171f095f1 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
81cae8c4-05cd-467f-a8d0-aea9bcc7e0ee Select young, tender pods. Remove and discard diseased and rust-spotted pods.
81cae8c4-05cd-467f-a8d0-aea9bcc7e0ee Procedure: Wash pods and trim ends. Leave whole or cut into 1 inch pieces.
81cae8c4-05cd-467f-a8d0-aea9bcc7e0ee Hot Pack - Cover with hot water in a saucepan, boil 2 minutes and drain. Fill hot jars with hot okra and cooking liquid, leaving 1-inch headspace. Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to pints, 1 teaspoon to quarts, if desired. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
81cae8c4-05cd-467f-a8d0-aea9bcc7e0ee For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
addca9d3-41c6-4a15-87ac-8047b0051cd6 All varieties
addca9d3-41c6-4a15-87ac-8047b0051cd6 Select mature, dry seeds. Sort out and discard discolored seeds.
addca9d3-41c6-4a15-87ac-8047b0051cd6 Procedure: Place dried peas in a large pot and cover with water. Soak 12 to 18 hours in a cool place. Drain water. To quickly hydrate peas, you may cover sorted and washed peas with boiling water in a saucepan. Boil 2 minutes, remove from heat, soak 1 hour and drain. Cover peas soaked by either method with fresh water and boil 30 minutes.
addca9d3-41c6-4a15-87ac-8047b0051cd6 Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt per pint or 1 teaspoon per quart to the jar, if desired. Fill hot jars with peas and cooking water, leaving 1-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
addca9d3-41c6-4a15-87ac-8047b0051cd6 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
10ffd9ae-1122-46d2-bce7-474b0d03b27d Shell and wash peas.
10ffd9ae-1122-46d2-bce7-474b0d03b27d Cover with boiling water. Bring to a boil in a saucepan, and boil for 2 minutes. Fill hot jars loosely with hot peas, and add cooking liquid, leaving 1-inch headspace. Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to pints, 1 teaspoon to quarts, if desired. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
10ffd9ae-1122-46d2-bce7-474b0d03b27d Fill hot jars with raw peas, add boiling water, leaving 1-inch headspace. Do not shake or press down peas. Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to pints, 1 teaspoon to quarts, if desired. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
10ffd9ae-1122-46d2-bce7-474b0d03b27d It is recommended that sugar snap and Chinese edible pods be frozen for best quality. Select filled pods containing young, tender, sweet seeds. Discard diseased pods.
10ffd9ae-1122-46d2-bce7-474b0d03b27d For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
10ffd9ae-1122-46d2-bce7-474b0d03b27d NOTE For dry peas follow procedures and processing times for dry beans.
293b09ee-9b1f-40ae-9cce-fb7a3a439491 Hot or sweet, including chiles, jalapeno, and pimiento.
293b09ee-9b1f-40ae-9cce-fb7a3a439491 Procedure: Select firm yellow, green, or red peppers. Do not use soft or diseased peppers.
293b09ee-9b1f-40ae-9cce-fb7a3a439491 CAUTION If you choose hot peppers, wear plastic or rubber gloves and do not touch your face while handling or cutting hot peppers. If you do not wear gloves, wash hands thoroughly with soap and water before touching your face or eyes. If you do touch your eyes you may have vision problems for 15-20 minutes, however, the condition is not threatening and the problem will go away. Remember, hot peppers are the main ingredient of self-defense pepper spray.
293b09ee-9b1f-40ae-9cce-fb7a3a439491 Hot Pack - Small peppers may be left whole. Large peppers may be quartered. Remove cores and seeds. Slash two or four slits in each pepper, and either blanch in boiling water or blister skins using one of these two methods:
293b09ee-9b1f-40ae-9cce-fb7a3a439491 Cool several minutes; peel off skins. Flatten whole peppers. Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to each pint jar, if desired. Fill hot jars loosely with peppers and add fresh boiling water, leaving 1-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
293b09ee-9b1f-40ae-9cce-fb7a3a439491 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
293b09ee-9b1f-40ae-9cce-fb7a3a439491 Oven or broiler method to blister skins ñ place peppers in a hot oven (400° F, 204° C) or broiler for 6-8 minutes until skins blister.
293b09ee-9b1f-40ae-9cce-fb7a3a439491 Range-top method to blister skins ñ Cover hot burner, either gas or electric, with heavy wire mesh. Place peppers on burner for several minutes until skins blister. After blistering skins, place peppers in a pan and cover with a damp cloth. (This will make peeling the peppers easier).
2790813b-8493-434e-a537-f8887518bf83 Choose small to medium-sized potatoes. They should be mature and not too fibrous. Can within 1 to 2 months after harvest.
2790813b-8493-434e-a537-f8887518bf83 Hot Pack - Wash potatoes and boil or steam until partially soft (15 to 20 minutes). Remove skins. Cut medium potatoes, if needed, so that pieces are uniform in size.
2790813b-8493-434e-a537-f8887518bf83 CAUTION Do not mash or puree pieces.
2790813b-8493-434e-a537-f8887518bf83 Fill hot jars, leaving 1-inch headspace. Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to pints, 1 teaspoon to quarts, if desired. Fill jars with hot water boiling water or syrup to 1 inch from top.
2790813b-8493-434e-a537-f8887518bf83 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
47b86cbe-6c3a-4d4e-ba97-738c6a130023 Select small to medium-size mature potatoes of ideal quality for cooking. Tubers stored below 45∞F may discolor when canned Choose potatoes 1 to 2 inches in diameter if they are to be packed whole.
47b86cbe-6c3a-4d4e-ba97-738c6a130023 Procedure: Wash and peel potatoes. If desired, cut into 1/2-inch cubes. To prevent darkening place potatoes in ascorbic acid solution. Drain.
47b86cbe-6c3a-4d4e-ba97-738c6a130023 Ascorbic acid solution: add 3000 mg (1 teaspoon) of ascorbic acid powder, or 6 crushed 500-milligram tablet of vitamin C to 1 gallon of water.
47b86cbe-6c3a-4d4e-ba97-738c6a130023 Hot Pack - Cook 2 minutes in boiling water and drain again. For whole potatoes, boil 10 minutes and drain. Fill hot jars with hot potatoes leaving 1-inch headspace. Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to pints, 1 teaspoon to quarts, if desired. Fill jars with boiling water to 1 inch from top. Remove air bubbles Adjust lids and process.
47b86cbe-6c3a-4d4e-ba97-738c6a130023 For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
fc058561-7659-47e1-9e91-0cd2661338ce Pumpkins and squash should have a hard rind and stringless, mature pulp of ideal quality for cooking fresh. Small size pumpkins (sugar or pie varieties) make better products.
fc058561-7659-47e1-9e91-0cd2661338ce Procedure: Wash, remove seeds, cut into 1-inch-wide slices, and peel. Cut flesh into 1-inch cubes. Boil 2 minutes in water.
fc058561-7659-47e1-9e91-0cd2661338ce CAUTION Do not mash or puree.
fc058561-7659-47e1-9e91-0cd2661338ce Hot Pack - Fill hot jars with cubes and boiling hot cooking liquid, leaving 1-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
fc058561-7659-47e1-9e91-0cd2661338ce For making pies, drain jars and strain or sieve the cubes at preparation time.
fc058561-7659-47e1-9e91-0cd2661338ce For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
fc058561-7659-47e1-9e91-0cd2661338ce Prepare and process according to instructions for "Pumpkin" above.
abe098c1-9587-441f-baa3-d25b247f6eef Vegetable, dried bean, pea, meat, poultry, or seafoods.
abe098c1-9587-441f-baa3-d25b247f6eef CAUTION Do not add noodles or other pasta, rice, flour, cream, milk or other thickening agents to home canned soups. If dried beans or peas are used, they must be fully rehydrated first.
abe098c1-9587-441f-baa3-d25b247f6eef Procedure: Select, wash, and prepare vegetables, meat, and seafoods as described for the specific foods. Cover meat with water and cook until tender. Cool meat and remove bones. Cook vegetables. For each cup of dried beans or peas, add 3 cups of water, boil 2 minutes, remove from heat, soak 1 hour, and heat to boil. Drain all foods and combine with meat broth, tomatoes, or water to cover. Boil 5 minutes.
abe098c1-9587-441f-baa3-d25b247f6eef CAUTION Do not thicken. Salt to taste, if desired.
abe098c1-9587-441f-baa3-d25b247f6eef Hot Pack - Fill hot jars only halfway with mixture of solids. Add and cover with remaining liquid, leaving 1-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
abe098c1-9587-441f-baa3-d25b247f6eef For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
fa520283-3f75-4a13-9ab7-d9a3a2f3fb5c Can only freshly harvested greens. Discard any wilted, discolored, diseased, or insect-damaged leaves. Leaves should be tender and attractive in color.
fa520283-3f75-4a13-9ab7-d9a3a2f3fb5c Procedure: Wash only small amounts of greens at one time. Drain water and continue rinsing until water is clear and free of grit. Cut out tough stems and midribs. Place 1 pound of greens at a time in cheesecloth bag or blancher basket and steam 3 to 5 minutes or until well wilted. Add 1/4 teaspoon of salt to pints and 1/2 teaspoon of salt to quarts, if desired.
fa520283-3f75-4a13-9ab7-d9a3a2f3fb5c Hot Pack - Fill hot jars loosely with greens and add fresh boiling water, leaving 1-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles, adjust lids and process.
fa520283-3f75-4a13-9ab7-d9a3a2f3fb5c * CAUTION process 100 minutes if soup contains seafoods.
fa520283-3f75-4a13-9ab7-d9a3a2f3fb5c For processing at above 1,000 ft, see Altitude Adjustments.
6d5af2e6-ef42-485b-a4b5-1e1487377185 Apple butter is a thickened apple sauce with added spices.
6d5af2e6-ef42-485b-a4b5-1e1487377185 Quarter and core apples, leave the skin on. Cook apples in vinegar and cider on low heat.
6d5af2e6-ef42-485b-a4b5-1e1487377185 Press apple pulp through a strainer or food mill. Put apple pulp in a pot and add sugar and spices.
6d5af2e6-ef42-485b-a4b5-1e1487377185 Cook on low heat until thick, stirring frequently. This will take about 60 minutes.
6d5af2e6-ef42-485b-a4b5-1e1487377185 Test for doneness – spoon a portion of apple butter into a plate. If a rim of liquid does not form around the butter, it has been properly cooked.
6d5af2e6-ef42-485b-a4b5-1e1487377185 Without a delay, fill sterile glass jars leaving ¼ inch headspace. Wipe rims, tighten lids and process in a bath canner for 5 minutes. At altitudes above 1000 feet, process for 10 minutes.
