Combine all ingredients in a large saucepan and heat, stirring frequently, until mixture boils. Reduce heat and simmer for 20 minutes, stirring occasionally. Fill hot salsa into hot pint jars, leaving 1/2-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
9888ac1d-21d5-4ae5-b45e-490c19979a8c Yield: About 5 pints
9888ac1d-21d5-4ae5-b45e-490c19979a8c CAUTION Wear plastic or rubber gloves and do not touch your face while handling or cutting hot peppers. If you do not wear gloves, wash hands thoroughly with soap and water before touching your face or eyes.
9888ac1d-21d5-4ae5-b45e-490c19979a8c Peel and prepare peppers
9888ac1d-21d5-4ae5-b45e-490c19979a8c Wash and dry peppers; slit each pepper along the side to allow steam to escape. Blister skins using one of these two methods:
9888ac1d-21d5-4ae5-b45e-490c19979a8c Oven or broiler method to blister skins - Place peppers in a hot oven (400° F) or under a broiler for 6 to 8 minutes until skins blister.
9888ac1d-21d5-4ae5-b45e-490c19979a8c Range-top method to blister skins - Cover hot burner (either gas or electric) with heavy wire mesh. Place peppers on burner for several minutes until skins blister.
9888ac1d-21d5-4ae5-b45e-490c19979a8c To peel, after blistering skins, place peppers in a pan and cover with a damp cloth. (This will make peeling the peppers easier.) Cool several minutes; peel off skins. Discard seeds and chop.
9888ac1d-21d5-4ae5-b45e-490c19979a8c Procedure: Combine all ingredients in a large saucepan and stir frequently over high heat until mixture begins to boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 20 minutes, stirring occasionally. Ladle hot salsa into hot pint jars, leaving 1/2-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
e9cc6d02-c770-424b-b0a5-c0ebeab83b69 Quantity: An average of 23 pounds is needed per canner load of 7 quarts, or an average of 14 pounds per canner load of 9 pints. A bushel weighs 53 pounds and yields 15 to 18 quarts of juice—an average of 3-1/4 pounds per quart.
e9cc6d02-c770-424b-b0a5-c0ebeab83b69 Procedure: Wash, remove stems, and trim off bruised or discolored portions. To prevent juice from separating, quickly cut about 1 pound of tomatoes into quarters and put directly into sauce- pan. Heat immediately to boiling while crushing. Continue to slowly add and crush freshly cut tomato quarters to the boiling mixture. Make sure the mixture boils constantly and vigorously while you add the remaining tomatoes. Simmer 5 minutes after you add all pieces.
e9cc6d02-c770-424b-b0a5-c0ebeab83b69 If you are not concerned about juice separation, simply slice or quarter tomatoes into a large saucepan. Crush, heat, and simmer for 5 minutes before juicing.
e9cc6d02-c770-424b-b0a5-c0ebeab83b69 Press both types of heated juice through a sieve or food mill to remove skins and seeds. Add bottled lemon juice or citric acid to jars. See acidification instructions on page 3-5. Heat juice again to boiling. Add 1 teaspoon of salt per quart to the jars, if desired. Fill hot jars with hot tomato juice, leaving 1/2-inch headspace. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process. (Acidification is still required for the pressure canning options; follow all steps in the Procedures above for any of the processing options.)
93094b36-de98-4a8c-95c7-0d3be039c052 Yield: 6 to 7 pints
93094b36-de98-4a8c-95c7-0d3be039c052 Procedure: Wash tomatoes. Dip in boiling water for 30 to 60 seconds or until skins split. Dip in cold water. Slip off skins and remove cores. Quarter tomatoes into 4-gallon stockpot or a large kettle. Add onions and red pepper. Bring to boil and simmer 20 minutes, uncovered. Cover, turn off heat and let stand for 20 minutes. Combine spices in a spice bag and add to vinegar in a 2-quart saucepan. Bring to boil. Remove spice bag and combine vinegar and tomato mixture. Boil about 30 minutes. Put boiled mixture through a food mill or sieve. Return to pot. Add sugar and salt, boil gently, and stir frequently until volume is reduced by one-half or until mixture rounds up on spoon without separation. Fill hot pint jars, leaving 1/8-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
d98f8001-7c64-415c-b8ca-16f277c3efac Yield: About 7 quarts
d98f8001-7c64-415c-b8ca-16f277c3efac CAUTION Wear plastic or rubber gloves and do not touch your face while handling or cutting hot peppers. If you do not wear gloves, wash hands thoroughly with soap and water before touching your face or eyes.
d98f8001-7c64-415c-b8ca-16f277c3efac Wash and dry chiles. Slit each pepper along the side to allow steam to escape. Blister skins using one of these two methods:
d98f8001-7c64-415c-b8ca-16f277c3efac Oven or broiler method to blister skins - Place peppers in a hot oven (400° F) or under a broiler for 6 to 8 minutes until skins blister.
d98f8001-7c64-415c-b8ca-16f277c3efac Range-top method to blister skins - Cover hot burner (either gas or electric) with heavy wire mesh. Place peppers on burner for several minutes until skins blister.
d98f8001-7c64-415c-b8ca-16f277c3efac After blistering skins, place peppers in a pan and cover with a damp cloth. (This will make peeling the peppers easier.) Cool several minutes; peel off skins. Discard seeds and chop pep- pers. Wash tomatoes and dip in boiling water for 30 to 60 seconds or until skins split. Dip in cold water, slip off skins, and remove cores. Coarsely chop tomatoes and combine chopped peppers and remaining ingredients in large saucepan. Bring to a boil. Cover. Reduce heat and simmer 10 minutes. Fill hot jars, leaving 1-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
bc1f49eb-4c90-42fb-9584-2ab2d9f41a8a Quantity: An average of 12 pounds of tomatoes and 4 pounds of okra or zucchini is needed per canner load of 7 quarts. An average of 7 pounds of tomatoes and 2-1/2 pounds of okra or zucchini is needed per canner load of 9 pints. (Use about 3 pounds tomatoes to 1 pound vegetable.)
bc1f49eb-4c90-42fb-9584-2ab2d9f41a8a Procedure: Wash tomatoes and okra or zucchini. Dip tomatoes in boiling water 30 to 60 seconds or until skins split. Then dip in cold water, slip off skins and remove cores, and quar- ter. Trim stems from okra and slice into 1-inch pieces or leave whole. Slice or cube zucchini if used. Bring tomatoes to a boil and simmer 10 minutes. Add okra or zucchini and boil gently 5 minutes. Add 1 teaspoon of salt for each quart to the jars, if desired. Fill hot jars with mix- ture, leaving 1-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
bc1f49eb-4c90-42fb-9584-2ab2d9f41a8a Variation: You may add four or five pear, onions or two onion slices to each jar.
7e9cd8df-c89c-4c9f-ba99-8839eeacfe32 Yield: About 7 to 9 pints
7e9cd8df-c89c-4c9f-ba99-8839eeacfe32 CAUTION Wear plastic or rubber gloves and do not touch your face while handling or cutting hot peppers. If you do not wear gloves, wash hands thoroughly with soap and water before touching your face or eyes.
7e9cd8df-c89c-4c9f-ba99-8839eeacfe32 Peel and prepare peppers
7e9cd8df-c89c-4c9f-ba99-8839eeacfe32 Wash and dry peppers; slit each pepper along the side to allow steam to escape. Blister skins using one of these two methods:
7e9cd8df-c89c-4c9f-ba99-8839eeacfe32 Oven or broiler method to blister skins - Place peppers in a hot oven (400° F) or under a broiler for 6 to 8 minutes until skins blister.
7e9cd8df-c89c-4c9f-ba99-8839eeacfe32 Range-top method to blister skins - Cover hot burner (either gas or electric) with heavy wire mesh. Place peppers on burner for several minutes until skins blister.
7e9cd8df-c89c-4c9f-ba99-8839eeacfe32 To peel, after blistering skins, place peppers in a pan and cover with a damp cloth. (This will make peeling the peppers easier.) Cool several minutes; peel off skins. Discard seeds and chop.
7e9cd8df-c89c-4c9f-ba99-8839eeacfe32 Procedure: Wash tomatoes and dip in boiling water for 30 to 60 seconds or until skins split. Dip in cold water, slip of skins, and remove cores. Combine all ingredients in a large saucepan. Bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer for 30 minutes, stirring occasionally. Fill hot salsa into hot pint jars, leaving 1/2-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
7b5d4747-62e9-43c0-95c6-30517d58a298 *This recipe works best with paste tomatoes. Slicing tomatoes require a much longer cooking time to achieve a desirable consistency.
7b5d4747-62e9-43c0-95c6-30517d58a298 Yield: About 16 to 18 pints
7b5d4747-62e9-43c0-95c6-30517d58a298 CAUTION Wear plastic or rubber gloves and do not touch your face while handling or cutting hot peppers. If you do not wear gloves, wash hands thoroughly with soap and water before touching your face or eyes.
7b5d4747-62e9-43c0-95c6-30517d58a298 Peel and prepare peppers
7b5d4747-62e9-43c0-95c6-30517d58a298 Wash and dry peppers; slit each pepper along the side to allow steam to escape. Blister skins using one of these two methods:
7b5d4747-62e9-43c0-95c6-30517d58a298 Oven or broiler method to blister skins - Place peppers in a hot oven (400° F) or under a broiler for 6 to 8 minutes until skins blister.
7b5d4747-62e9-43c0-95c6-30517d58a298 Range-top method to blister skins - Cover hot burner (either gas or electric) with heavy wire mesh. Place peppers on burner for several minutes until skins blister.
7b5d4747-62e9-43c0-95c6-30517d58a298 To peel, after blistering skins, place peppers in a pan and cover with a damp cloth. (This will make peeling the peppers easier.) Cool several minutes; peel off skins. Discard seeds and chop.
7b5d4747-62e9-43c0-95c6-30517d58a298 Procedure: Wash tomatoes and dip in boiling water for 30 to 60 seconds or until skins split. Dip in cold water, slip off skins, and remove cores. Combine all ingredients except cumin, oregano and cilantro in a large pot and bring to a boil, stirring frequently, then reduce heat and simmer for 10 minutes. Add spices and simmer for another 20 minutes, stirring occasionally. Fill hot salsa into hot pint jars, leaving 1/2-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
2850c6de-ca59-4889-9088-52b3be5a9b6b Yield: About 4 pints
2850c6de-ca59-4889-9088-52b3be5a9b6b CAUTION Wear plastic or rubber gloves and do not touch your face while handling or cutting hot peppers. If you do not wear gloves, wash hands thoroughly with soap and water before touching your face or eyes.
2850c6de-ca59-4889-9088-52b3be5a9b6b Peel and prepare peppers
2850c6de-ca59-4889-9088-52b3be5a9b6b Wash and dry peppers; slit each pepper along the side to allow steam to escape. Blister skins using one of these two methods:
2850c6de-ca59-4889-9088-52b3be5a9b6b Oven or broiler method to blister skins - Place peppers in a hot oven (400° F) or under a broiler for 6 to 8 minutes until skins blister.
2850c6de-ca59-4889-9088-52b3be5a9b6b Range-top method to blister skins - Cover hot burner (either gas or electric) with heavy wire mesh. Place peppers on burner for several minutes until skins blister.
2850c6de-ca59-4889-9088-52b3be5a9b6b To peel, after blistering skins, place peppers in a pan and cover with a damp cloth. (This will make peeling the peppers easier.) Cool several minutes; peel off skins. Discard seeds and chop.
2850c6de-ca59-4889-9088-52b3be5a9b6b Procedure: Wash tomatoes and dip in boiling water for 30 to 60 seconds or until skins split. Dip in cold water, slip off skins, and remove cores. Combine all ingredients in a large pot and bring to a boil, stirring frequently. Reduce heat and simmer 20 minutes, stirring occasionally. Fill hot salsa into hot pint jars, leaving 1/2-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
b3f68588-8c12-43a2-8378-a96f8fc208ea Quantity: For thin sauce—an average of 35 pounds is needed per canner load of 7 quarts; an average of 21 pounds is needed per canner load of 9 pints. A bushel weighs 53 pounds and yields 10 to 12 quarts of sauce—an average of 5 pounds per quart. For thick sauce—an aver- age of 46 pounds is needed per canner load of 7 quarts; an average of 28 pounds is needed per canner load of 9 pints. A bushel weighs 53 pounds and yields 7 to 9 quarts of thick sauce—an average of 6-1/2 pounds per quart.
b3f68588-8c12-43a2-8378-a96f8fc208ea Procedure: Prepare and press as for making tomato juice, see page 3-5. Simmer in large- diameter saucepan until sauce reaches desired consistency. Boil until volume is reduced by about one-third for thin sauce, or by one-half for thick sauce. Add bottled lemon juice or citric acid to jars. See acidification directions on page 3-5. Add 1 teaspoon of salt per quart to the jars, if desired. Fill hot jars, leaving 1/4-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process. (Acidification is still required for the pressure canning options; follow all steps in the Procedures above for any of the processing options.)
deeb0663-9767-4d39-9945-5a9f7d8d9068 Yield: About 9 pints
deeb0663-9767-4d39-9945-5a9f7d8d9068 Procedure: To prepare tomatoes, follow directions for Spaghetti Sauce Without Meat. Saute beef or sausage until brown. Add garlic, onion, celery or green pepper, and mushrooms, if desired. Cook until vegetables are tender. Combine with tomato pulp in large saucepan. Add spices, salt, and sugar. Bring to a boil. Simmer, uncovered, until thick enough for serving. At this time initial volume will have been reduced by nearly one-half. Stir frequently to avoid burning. Fill hot jars, leaving 1-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
34c3b6bb-82ef-46e4-94a0-517e59a0f1b0 Yield: About 9 pints
34c3b6bb-82ef-46e4-94a0-517e59a0f1b0 CAUTION Do not increase the proportion of onions, peppers, or mushrooms.
34c3b6bb-82ef-46e4-94a0-517e59a0f1b0 Procedure: Wash tomatoes and dip in boiling water for 30 to 60 seconds or until skins split. Dip in cold water and slip off skins. Remove cores and quarter tomatoes. Boil 20 minutes, uncovered, in large saucepan. Put through food mill or sieve. Saute onions, garlic, celery or peppers, and mushrooms (if desired) in vegetable oil until tender. Combine sauteed vegetables and tomatoes and add remainder of spices, salt, and sugar. Bring to a boil. Simmer, uncovered, until thick enough for serving. At this time the initial volume will have been reduced by nearly one-half. Stir frequently to avoid burning. Fill hot jars, leaving 1-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
0536e32f-0c97-47b2-bf93-dd28588af41c This recipe works best with paste tomatoes, as slicing tomatoes will yield a thin watery salsa. If you only have slicing tomatoes available, use the Tomato/Tomato Paste Salsa recipe.
0536e32f-0c97-47b2-bf93-dd28588af41c Yield: About 16 to 18 pints
0536e32f-0c97-47b2-bf93-dd28588af41c CAUTION Wear plastic or rubber gloves and do not touch your face while handling or cutting hot peppers. If you do not wear gloves, wash hands thoroughly with soap and water before touching your face or eyes.
0536e32f-0c97-47b2-bf93-dd28588af41c Peel and prepare peppers
0536e32f-0c97-47b2-bf93-dd28588af41c Wash and dry peppers; slit each pepper along the side to allow steam to escape. Blister skins using one of these two methods:
0536e32f-0c97-47b2-bf93-dd28588af41c Oven or broiler method to blister skins - Place peppers in a hot oven (400° F) or under a broiler for 6 to 8 minutes until skins blister.
0536e32f-0c97-47b2-bf93-dd28588af41c Range-top method to blister skins - Cover hot burner (either gas or electric) with heavy wire mesh. Place peppers on burner for several minutes until skins blister.
0536e32f-0c97-47b2-bf93-dd28588af41c To peel, after blistering skins, place peppers in a pan and cover with a damp cloth. (This will make peeling the peppers easier.) Cool several minutes; peel off skins. Discard seeds and chop.
0536e32f-0c97-47b2-bf93-dd28588af41c Procedure: Wash tomatoes and dip in boiling water for 30 to 60 seconds or until skins split. Dip in cold water, slip of skins, and remove cores. Combine all ingredients in a large saucepan. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer, stirring frequently until thick (about 1 hour). Fill hot sauce into hot pint jars, leaving 1/2-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
cc879e37-9ccb-4a16-9fa8-26a4c133504e Quantity: An average of 14 pounds is needed per canner load of 7 quarts; an average of 9 pounds is needed per canner load of 9 pints. A bushel weighs 32 pounds and yields 14 to 16 quarts—an average of 2 pounds per quart.
cc879e37-9ccb-4a16-9fa8-26a4c133504e Quality: Select unblemished firm, deep bright green tomatillos with a dry papery husk.
cc879e37-9ccb-4a16-9fa8-26a4c133504e Procedure: Remove the dry outer husks entirely from the tomatillos and wash the fruit well. Leave whole; do not peel or remove seeds. Add bottled lemon juice or citric acid to jars. Follow the acidification amounts for tomatoes on page 3-5. Add enough water to cover the tomatillos in a large saucepan and boil them gently until tender, about 5 to 10 minutes. Drain and fill hot tomatillos loosely into hot jars, leaving 1/2-inch headspace. Fill hot jars with boil- ing water, leaving 1/2-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.
cc879e37-9ccb-4a16-9fa8-26a4c133504e Process the same as Water-Packed Whole Tomatoes, Hot Pack.
c9571388-4501-422b-a7c6-e1abcebb9c57 Quantity: An average of 22 pounds of tomatoes is needed per canner load of 7 quarts. No more than 3 cups of other vegetables may be added for each 22 pounds of tomatoes.
c9571388-4501-422b-a7c6-e1abcebb9c57 Procedure: Crush and simmer tomatoes as for making tomato juice (see page 3-5). Add no more than 3 cups of any combination of finely chopped celery, onions, carrots, and peppers for each 22 lbs of tomatoes. Simmer mixture 20 minutes. Press hot cooked tomatoes and vegetables through a sieve or food mill to remove skins and seeds. Add bottled lemon juice or citric acid to jars. See acidification directions on page 3-5. Add 1 teaspoon of salt per quart to the jars, if desired. Reheat tomato-vegetable juice blend to boiling and fill immediately into hot jars, leaving 1/2-inch headspace. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process. (Acidification is still required for the pressure canning options; fol- low all steps in the Procedures above for any of the processing options.)
d26144f7-9e1b-46d7-be1d-f3f1235c76b1 Yield: 6 to 7 pints
d26144f7-9e1b-46d7-be1d-f3f1235c76b1 Procedure: Follow procedure and process time for regular tomato ketchup.
101941db-4f6f-4170-a862-a78e058e9554 Quantity: See whole tomatoes packed in water.
101941db-4f6f-4170-a862-a78e058e9554 Procedure: Wash tomatoes. Dip in boiling water for 30 to 60 seconds or until skins split, then dip in cold water. Slip off skins and remove cores. Leave whole or halve. Add bottled lemon juice or citric acid to the jars. See acidification instructions on page 3-5. Add 1 tea- spoon of salt per quart to the jars, if desired.
101941db-4f6f-4170-a862-a78e058e9554 Raw pack - Heat tomato juice in a saucepan. Fill hot jars with raw tomatoes, leaving 1/2-inch headspace. Cover tomatoes in the jars with hot tomato juice, leaving 1/2-inch headspace.
101941db-4f6f-4170-a862-a78e058e9554 Hot pack - Put tomatoes in a large saucepan and add enough tomato juice to completely cover them. Boil tomatoes and juice gently for 5 minutes. Fill hot jars with hot tomatoes, leaving 1/2-inch headspace. Add hot tomato juice to the jars to cover the tomatoes, leaving 1/2-inch headspace.
101941db-4f6f-4170-a862-a78e058e9554 Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process. (Acidification is still required for the pressure canning options; follow all steps in the Procedures above for any of the processing options.)
1b57c878-e615-494c-bfb7-f2fb3d4f1b93 Quantity: An average of 21 pounds is needed per canner load of 7 quarts; an average of 13 pounds is needed per canner load of 9 pints. A bushel weighs 53 pounds and yields 15 to 21 quarts—an average of 3 pounds per quart.
1b57c878-e615-494c-bfb7-f2fb3d4f1b93 Procedure for hot or raw tomatoes filled with water in jars: Wash tomatoes. Dip in boiling water for 30 to 60 seconds or until skins split; then dip in cold water. Slip off skins and re- move cores. Leave whole or halve. Add bottled lemon juice or citric acid to jars. See acidifica- tion directions on page 3-5. Add 1 teaspoon of salt per quart to the jars, if desired. For hot pack products, add enough water to cover the tomatoes and boil them gently for 5 minutes. Fill hot jars with hot tomatoes or with raw peeled tomatoes. Add the hot cooking liquid to the hot pack, or hot water for raw pack to cover, leaving 1/2-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process. (Acidification is still required for the pressure canning op- tions; follow all steps in the Procedures above for any of the processing options.)

bfb3bef4-317d-419e-857c-e22483536b6b marjoram
bfb3bef4-317d-419e-857c-e22483536b6b 1/2 small onion
bfb3bef4-317d-419e-857c-e22483536b6b allspice

bfb3bef4-317d-419e-857c-e22483536b6b 1/2 Pint jars - 50 min
bfb3bef4-317d-419e-857c-e22483536b6b Pint jars - 60 min
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 salt
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 pepper
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 paprika
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 marjoram
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 ginger
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 onion
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 a. Wash raw skins in lukewarm water.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 b. Cure skins for 2 days in 18° Be (70° salinometer, 18% salt) at refrigerator temperature. Use enough solution to be able to mix the skins without difficulty. 70° SAL solution: 1.88 lb salt to 1 gallon of water.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 c. Simmer the skins for 25 minutes at 194-203° F, 90-95° C, but don't make them too soft.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 d. Cool the skins on screens as warm skins stick together during grinding.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 a. Cut I, II and III beef into 3/4 - 1 inch (20 - 25 mm) pieces. You can use grinder with the kidney plate.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 b. Grind skins and other meats through 1/8" (3 mm) plate.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 350 ml jar - 50 min
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 500 ml jar - 60 min
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 Continue after step 5.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 6. Fill the cans leaving 1/2 inch headspace.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 7. Exhaust cans to 170° F, 77° C meat temperature.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 8. Fill the cans with hot boiling water to 1/4 inch from top.
37f02e80-18a6-45fe-ac53-bd6daeadb2b9 9. Process at once at 250° F, 121° C:

ea3b9668-0f31-4427-87c0-dde6d5c07c09 pork ribs, smoked
ea3b9668-0f31-4427-87c0-dde6d5c07c09 pork ribs
ea3b9668-0f31-4427-87c0-dde6d5c07c09 pork bones
ea3b9668-0f31-4427-87c0-dde6d5c07c09 lard
ea3b9668-0f31-4427-87c0-dde6d5c07c09 a. Strain sauerkraut and remove about 30% of the juice in relation to the original weight. Keep the juice in case the bigos is not sourly enogh. The juice can be added during cooking cabbage.
ea3b9668-0f31-4427-87c0-dde6d5c07c09 b. If you find your sauerkraut too acidic, rinse it with water and strain.
ea3b9668-0f31-4427-87c0-dde6d5c07c09 c. Cut the skinless cured bacon into 2 cm x 2.5 cm cm strips, dry and smoke with warm smoke for 4 hours. Cool bacon and cut into 3 mm (1/8") diameter strips.
ea3b9668-0f31-4427-87c0-dde6d5c07c09 d. Rinse dry mushrooms 3-4 times in cold water, then soak them for 30 min in cold water. Remove, drain and cut into 2 mm (1/8") strips.
ea3b9668-0f31-4427-87c0-dde6d5c07c09 e. Wash bones in cold water.
ea3b9668-0f31-4427-87c0-dde6d5c07c09 f. Cut beef and pork into 20 mm (3/4") cubes. Cut the sausage into 3 mm (1/8") discs. Cut onion into 5 mm (1/4") cubes. If using larger amounts of materials use a grinder with an appropriate plate.
14623541-e974-4d16-a709-b5853ac2b7b6 pork ribs
14623541-e974-4d16-a709-b5853ac2b7b6 pork bones
14623541-e974-4d16-a709-b5853ac2b7b6 lard
14623541-e974-4d16-a709-b5853ac2b7b6 a. Strain sauerkraut and remove about 30% of the juice in relation to the original weight. Keep the juice in case the bigos is not sourly enough. The juice can be added during cooking cabbage.
14623541-e974-4d16-a709-b5853ac2b7b6 b. If you find your sauerkraut too acidic, rinse it with water and strain.
14623541-e974-4d16-a709-b5853ac2b7b6 c. Cut the skinless cured bacon into 2 cm x 2.5 cm cm strips, dry and smoke with warm smoke for 4 hours. Cool bacon and cut into 3 mm (1/8") diameter strips.
14623541-e974-4d16-a709-b5853ac2b7b6 d. Rinse dry mushrooms 3-4 times in cold water, then soak them for 30 min in cold water. Remove, drain and cut into 2 mm (1/8") strips.
14623541-e974-4d16-a709-b5853ac2b7b6 e. Wash bones in cold water.
14623541-e974-4d16-a709-b5853ac2b7b6 f. Cut beef and pork into 20 mm (3/4") cubes. Cut the sausage into 3 mm (1/8") discs. Cut onion into 5 mm (1/4") cubes. If using larger amounts of materials use a grinder with an appropriate plate.
14623541-e974-4d16-a709-b5853ac2b7b6 1. Place bones and ribs in a skillet and add enough water to cover them. Bring to a boil, reduce heat, cover with a lid and simmer until the meat is semi-soft. Remove the ribs and separate the meat from the bones. Place bones back in the skillet and simmer for additional 3 hours. Remove bone and remove all meat. Filter the stock through a fine sieve. Cut the rib meat into 30 mm (3/4") pieces.
14623541-e974-4d16-a709-b5853ac2b7b6 2. Place cabbage in a pot and add equal by weight amount of the meat stock. Add caraway, bay leaf and cut up mushrooms and simmer everything together for 4 hours. Do not cover with the lid. Replace the meat stock lost during evaporation with more meat stock.
14623541-e974-4d16-a709-b5853ac2b7b6 3. Melt 1/2 lard in a frying pan, then fry cut up onion just to soften it. Add beef and pork cubes and simmer for 30 minutes. Add bacon, sausage, tomato sauce and simmer for additional 20 minutes. Stir often to prevent burning.
14623541-e974-4d16-a709-b5853ac2b7b6 4. Add the following to the cooked cabbage: browned beef and pork, onion, salt, all boiled meat that was separated from the bones, and simmer for 60 minutes, stirring often. The stew should not be covered with liquid sauce, however, the sauce should come up when the stew is pressed with the spoon. Let it cool enough to be able to handle it. Sprinkle pepper and remix the stew.
14623541-e974-4d16-a709-b5853ac2b7b6 5. Fill 307x200.25 mm cans with hot stew leaving 1/4 inch headspace.
14623541-e974-4d16-a709-b5853ac2b7b6 6. Process at 240° F, 116° C for 60 minutes.

f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b salt
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b pepper
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b allspice
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b marjoram
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b small onion
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b 1. Skins.
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b a. Wash raw skins in lukewarm water.
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b b. Cure skins for 48 hours in 18° Be (70° salinometer, 18% salt) at refrigerator temperature. Use enough solution to be able to mix the skins without difficulty. 70° SAL solution: 1.88 lb salt to 1 gallon of water.
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b c. Simmer the skins for 25 minutes at 194-203° F, 90-95° C, but don't make them too soft.
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b d. Cool the skins on screens as warm skins glue together during grinding.
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b 2. Dice onion and fry in lard until golden.
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b 3. Cut pork and veal into 1" (25 mm) pieces.
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b 4. Grind skins through 1/8" (3 mm) plate.
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b 5. Mix meats with ground skins adding salt, until the mixture becomes sticky. Add onion and spices and remix.
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b 6. Pack the cans leaving 1/2 inch headspace.
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b 7. Exhaust cans to 170° F, 77° C meat temperature.
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b 8. Add hot boiling water (if needed) 1/4 inch to top.
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b 9. Process at once at 250° F, 121° C:
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b No.2.5, 401x411 - 80 min
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b 307x409 - 70 min
f7d4838b-37c4-4db7-9960-91d07122438b 307x200.25 - 50 min
2589d490-db5e-4b14-9ecf-788156515108 salt
2589d490-db5e-4b14-9ecf-788156515108 Cure #1

2589d490-db5e-4b14-9ecf-788156515108 potato flour
093873a8-8347-4b10-bfd8-9f0e88859f80 salt for curing
093873a8-8347-4b10-bfd8-9f0e88859f80 Cure #1
093873a8-8347-4b10-bfd8-9f0e88859f80 mustard seeds
093873a8-8347-4b10-bfd8-9f0e88859f80 bay leaf

093873a8-8347-4b10-bfd8-9f0e88859f80 * Instead of commercial gelatin a natural gelatin can be obtained by making strong stock from pig feet or skins.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 salt
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 pepper
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 marjoram
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 onion
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 1. Remove any visible fat from pork cuts.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 2. Heads. If the jowl is attached to the head remove it.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 a. Soak pork heads in cold water for 4 hours. Change water twice.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 b. Cook heads for 30 minutes in boiling water, then lower the temperature to 194-203° F, 90-95° C and simmer the heads until the meat can be separated from bones. This will take about 90 minutes. Do not overcook the meat.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 c. Place the heads on the table and cool until they can be handled.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 d. Separate all meat from bones, remove the tough ear tissue.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 3. Skins.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 a. Wash raw skins in lukewarm water.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 b. Cure skins for 2 days in 18° Be (70° salinometer, 18% salt) at refrigerator temperature. Use enough solution to be able to mix the skins without difficulty. 70° SAL solution: 1.88 lb salt to 1 gallon of water.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 c. Simmer the skins for 25 minutes at 194-203° F, 90-95° C, but don't make them too soft.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 d. Cool the skins on screens as warm skins glue together during grinding.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 4. Finely chop the onion and fry in lard until golden.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 5. Grinding meat.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 a. Cut I and II pork into 3/4 - 1 inch (20 - 25 mm) pieces. You can use grinder with the kidney plate.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 b. Grind head meat through 3/8" (10 mm) plate.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 c. Grind skins through 1/8" (3 mm) plate or smaller. If no small plate is available, run them through a food processor.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 6. Mix all meats with spices until mixture becomes sticky.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 7. Fill the jars leaving 1 inch headspace.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 8. Process at once at 250° F, 121° C:
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 1/2 Pint jars (236 ml) - 50 min
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 Pint jars (473 ml) - 60 min
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 NOTE Original processing times for metric jars were:
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 350 ml jar - 50 min
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 500 ml jar - 60 min
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 Continue after step 6.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 7. Fill the cans leaving 1/2 inch headspace.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 8. Exhaust cans to 170° F, 77° C meat temperature.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 9. Fill the cans with hot boiling water to 1/4 inch from top.
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 10. Process at once at 250° F, 121° C:
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 99x119 mm - 80 min
eb387e08-8fa2-4572-aba1-a819d57cbec5 99x63 mm - 50 min

427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 Use about one-third fat pork and two-thirds lean pork.
427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 Mix seasonings and sprinkle over the meat before grinding.
427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 For a fine, even sausage it should be run through the grinder a second, time.
427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 5 level teaspoons salt
427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 2 level teaspoons ground marjoram
427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 1 level teaspoon sugar
427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 1 level tablespoon pepper
427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 1 level teaspoon ground cloves or 1/2 tsp. nutmeg, if desired.
427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 The above amount may be made to test the recipe, if desired.
427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 2-1/2 cups salt
427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 1 cup group marjoram
427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 1/2 cup sugar (omit if it is expected that sausage will not be used reasonable soon)
427944dd-ca93-4961-8132-0f03eadd5756 1-1/2 cups pepper
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c 30 lbs tomatoes
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c 2-1/2 lbs ground beef or sausage
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c 5 cloves garlic, minced
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c 1 cup chopped onions
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c 1 cup chopped celery or green peppers
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c 1 lb fresh mushrooms, sliced (optional)
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c 4-1/2 tsp salt
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c 2 Tbsp oregano
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c 4 Tbsp minced parsley
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c 2 tsp black pepper
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c 1/4 cup brown sugar
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c Yield: About 9 pints
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c Wash tomatoes and dip in boiling water for 30 to 60 seconds or until skins split. Dip in cold water and slip off skins. Remove cores and quarter tomatoes. Boil 20 minutes, uncovered, in large saucepan. Put through food mill or sieve.
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c Saute beef or sausage until brown. Add garlic, onion, celery or green pepper, and mushrooms, if desired. Cook until vegetables are tender.
bcc52461-2f55-486c-aaa4-0e4b48d1651c Combine with tomato pulp in large sauce pan. Add spices, salt, and sugar. Bring to a boil. Simmer, uncovered, until thick enough for serving. At this time initial volume will have been reduced by nearly one-half. Stir frequently to avoid burning. Fill hot jars, leaving 1-inch headspace. Remove air bubbles and adjust headspace if needed. Wipe rims of jars with a dampened clean paper towel. Adjust lids and process.

955dd18a-54c0-4e35-a94f-622c0fc7fe00 Processing steps 1-4 remain the same.
955dd18a-54c0-4e35-a94f-622c0fc7fe00 5. Pack 550 g (19.40 oz) of tripe mixture in the can and pour 280 ml (9.47 oz) of beef stock, leaving 1/2 inch headspace.
955dd18a-54c0-4e35-a94f-622c0fc7fe00 6. Exhaust cans to 170° F, 77° C meat temperature. Remove air bubbles and ad hot boiling stock to 1/4 inch from top.
955dd18a-54c0-4e35-a94f-622c0fc7fe00 7. Seal and process at once at 250° F, 121° C:
955dd18a-54c0-4e35-a94f-622c0fc7fe00 401x411 can - 60 min
ffcecd10-919b-4711-afe1-4b70a9b11b88 Grind meat through 3mm 1/8 inch plate
ffcecd10-919b-4711-afe1-4b70a9b11b88 Ground fish, 1.5 kg, 3.5 lb
ffcecd10-919b-4711-afe1-4b70a9b11b88 Milk, 1 cup
ffcecd10-919b-4711-afe1-4b70a9b11b88 Fish broth*, 1 cup
ffcecd10-919b-4711-afe1-4b70a9b11b88 Flour, 3 Tbsp
ffcecd10-919b-4711-afe1-4b70a9b11b88 Fish sauce, 5 Tbsp
ffcecd10-919b-4711-afe1-4b70a9b11b88 Nutmeg, 1 tsp
ffcecd10-919b-4711-afe1-4b70a9b11b88 Pepper, 2 tsp
ffcecd10-919b-4711-afe1-4b70a9b11b88 Ginger, 1/3 tsp
ffcecd10-919b-4711-afe1-4b70a9b11b88 * simmer fish bones, in little water for 60 minutes.
ffcecd10-919b-4711-afe1-4b70a9b11b88 Mix all ingredients together, then add ground fish and remix again.
ffcecd10-919b-4711-afe1-4b70a9b11b88 Form the mixture into balls about 2 inch thick.
ffcecd10-919b-4711-afe1-4b70a9b11b88 Fry the balls in hot oil (375° F, 190° C) until light brown. This should not take longer than 1 minute. Pack into containers and fill with hot fish broth or light tomato sauce. Leave 1 inch headspace in glass jars, and 1/4 inch headspace in cans.
ffcecd10-919b-4711-afe1-4b70a9b11b88 Seal and process at once.
cecf139f-636d-4bd5-9783-f0ca2be2a59f Gut and clean the fish. Soak in 20% brine for 60 minutes and then fillet.
cecf139f-636d-4bd5-9783-f0ca2be2a59f Lay fillet on screens and smoke at 100° F, 38° C for 90 minutes.
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 1 quart canned tomatoes
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 1 Tbsp chopped parsley
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 3 or 4 whole cloves
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 Few drops Tobasco sauce
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 1 medium onion
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 Piece of bay leaf
efb2f0be-220d-4b9a-b956-242cd69b5379 1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce
ee2c91bd-600d-4ecc-a278-2e51c9e3fd36 Gut and clean the fish. Soak in 20% brine for 60 minutes and then smoke at 100° F, 38° C for 90 minutes.
ee2c91bd-600d-4ecc-a278-2e51c9e3fd36 Cut the smoked fish to fit the cans.
ee2c91bd-600d-4ecc-a278-2e51c9e3fd36 Pack the fish solidly leaving 1/4 inch headspace.
ee2c91bd-600d-4ecc-a278-2e51c9e3fd36 Exhaust. Place a suitable pot or pan on the stove with some hot water in it. Have more hot water nearby.
ee2c91bd-600d-4ecc-a278-2e51c9e3fd36 Place filled with fish open cans in the hot water in a single layer. The water should come up halfway up the outside of the cans. Do not cover cans with the lids. Covering the pot will result in moisture dripping into the cans.
ee2c91bd-600d-4ecc-a278-2e51c9e3fd36 Turn heat on high and bring water to boil. Adjust the heat to keep a steady boil.
ee2c91bd-600d-4ecc-a278-2e51c9e3fd36 Heat the pot until the fish reach a temperature of 170∞ F, 77∞ C. Using a jar lifter remove cans from the pot and seal one can at a time.
ee2c91bd-600d-4ecc-a278-2e51c9e3fd36 Place sealed cans on the rack in the canner. The canner should be already filled with about 3 inches of hot water.
ee2c91bd-600d-4ecc-a278-2e51c9e3fd36 Check your canner specifications.
ee2c91bd-600d-4ecc-a278-2e51c9e3fd36 Process at once.
1eed4e09-ee9d-4a6e-8816-0798c7fe8dcb Peel the shrimp from their shells.
1eed4e09-ee9d-4a6e-8816-0798c7fe8dcb Wash the shrimp and place into 10% (40° salinometer) brine for 10 minutes. Stir the shrimp after 5 minutes. To make brine dissolve 1 lb of salt in 1 gallon of water.
1eed4e09-ee9d-4a6e-8816-0798c7fe8dcb Remove shrimp and drop them into a fresh boiling 10% brine for 6 minutes. Drain and place on the screen until the surface moisture evaporates away, then pack into containers without a delay.
1eed4e09-ee9d-4a6e-8816-0798c7fe8dcb Pack shrimp into into glass jars to within 1-1/4 from the top. About 5 ounces of shrimp are put into 8 oz (1/2 pint) jar.
1eed4e09-ee9d-4a6e-8816-0798c7fe8dcb Fill glass jars with a hot 1% brine. To make brine dissolve 0.70 oz (20 g = 3 teaspoons) salt in 1 gallon of water.
1eed4e09-ee9d-4a6e-8816-0798c7fe8dcb Leave 1 inch headspace. Seal and process at once.
1eed4e09-ee9d-4a6e-8816-0798c7fe8dcb Pack shrimp into cans to within 1/2 inch from the top.
1eed4e09-ee9d-4a6e-8816-0798c7fe8dcb Fill glass jars with a hot 1% brine. Leave 1/4 inch headsets. To make brine dissolve 0.35 oz (10 g) salt in 1 gallon of water. Seal and process at once.

bb6b1fd4-1fd3-4547-bf69-6e3784bc181d Large beans - leave 1-inch of headspace for pints and 1-1/4 inches for quarts.
